name: Mr SPEAKER
Martin, Stephen, MP
text:
—At the outset one cannot help but remark that the Minister for Defence has gone AWOL without facing the charge. Let us hope that somebody is out there getting the security attendants in their new uniforms to rustle him up and bring him back in here to answer for the absolute shambles of a policy which he is trying to oversee within the Department of Defence. Once again in question time—as occurred yesterday—we witnessed Amateur Hour  when the Minister for Defence, laughingly a cabinet minister, stood in this place and scoffed at tradition and at questions being put to him that went to the heart of the  administration of an $11 billion a year Public Service department charged with the defence of Australia. The minister glibly said, in response to questions put to him on everything ranging from personnel matters through to security arrangements for Australia, `Well, everyone knows what the government's policy is,' and sat down to raucous laughter from his colleagues. Well, they must really think that Australia is just so well connected out there in the rest of the world that he can get away with that nonsense.
Yesterday, the minister went on to say that he expected the highest standards of management from his department. Well, we expect the highest standards of management of his department from this minister. Yesterday we also saw reports that this man who oversights this department referred to senior personnel—and I understand the protocols of this place—as f-wits. We all know what that means. It is 
 reported in the newspaper that this minister referred to senior people in his department in those terms. I find it incredible, but I can also understand why so many leaks are coming out of the Department of Defence. He really knows how to endear himself—the Minister for Defence—going around talking about people like that. But he has a bit of form, this bloke. When he came into government after 1996, he sacked his head of department. Now, of course, he is about trying to sack another bureaucrat, another head of his department.
The Barratt case raises some very interesting circumstances. I understand that, because of sub judice conventions and so on, we cannot go to the merits of the case or otherwise, but what we can do is point out some of the media commentary on this. It really is Days of Our Lives stuff. Mr Barratt was headhunted by the Prime Minister of this country and put into Defence after serving some time in Primary Industries. Because he survived a lemon hunt by Max `the Axe' Moore-Wilton trying to suss out those departmental heads that were no good and they reckoned he was pretty flash, he was given a performance based pay increase. Mr Moore, unfortunately, is a bit unhappy with him, but we do not know why, we do not know how long he has been unhappy with him. He has been distracted from all the duties he is supposed to perform as the Minister for Defence. We have the CDF, Admiral Barrie, saying that senior uniformed personnel have absolutely lost confidence in this minister. We have seen the CDF walking along arm in arm with Mr Barratt for photo opportunities—they are as one, and who is missing out of that little photograph? The minister. The minister is not there with his two senior people that run the defence department.
The minister is renowned for his sackings—it does not stop with departmental heads. He has gone through the Chief of Navy and his Assistant Secretary Acquisitions. I think Major General Hartley is in for the chop after today. Major General Hartley has blown the whistle on the lack of availability of medicos to serve people in the ADF—in times of war certainly but also in times of peace. We are talking about when they go on exercises, like 
 Crocodile that is on at present, when they go to Shoalwater Bay and they are performing duties and training as soldiers, sailors and airmen. The only trouble is we do not have anybody to fix them up if they get crook or if there is an accident. But the minister said, `Don't worry. Everything's all right. I am assured that volunteers will be there at some stage down the track.' Maybe.
This botched attempt to remove Mr Barratt really does take on the parameters of The Bold and the Beautiful. The Canberra Times reported recently some of the details about how he went about sacking this person, quoting from an affidavit given by Max `the Axe' Moore-Wilton. It was fascinating stuff. Max said:
"I said to him, `Jesus Christ, the trouble with you blokes is you have no corporate memory. Barratt put up with years of this from the Labor Party. He has already been an ambassador and he hates Foreign'.
So you are trying to sack the bloke who is head of Defence, and you are going to put him in Foreign Affairs but he hates Foreign Affairs because he came from there once before.
The article continues:
"McIntosh thinks you might be interested—
this is Barratt—
in going to university in the US to learn about defence.
So Sir Malcolm McIntosh, who the minister wants to put in on a six months contract to look after Defence to sort out its problems—and only six months when it probably needs a five-year focus—has decided that the bloke who runs Defence at the moment needs to go to the US to a university to learn about defence. Do not ask me why, if he has got the sack, because he ain't comin' back. He is not coming back to Australia to run Defence. The article gets better. It goes on to say:
Mr Barratt's affidavit also quoted Mr Moore-Wilton telling him that [Foreign Minister Alexander] Downer—
and this is one of the other big three over there that we saw today, and they are pretty good—
"is collaborating in this because Ric Smith— 

our ambassador in China—
is due out of China and there isn't a job for him in Foreign at the present time. The PM's office is also playing a hand in it."
Mr Barratt said he had replied that he had not the faintest interest in New Zealand, but "I might be tempted by Paris", to which Mr Moore-Wilton replied that "the trouble is that his mate likes it there".
Who is his mate? It is John Spender. John Spender is already in Paris and he is not going to come out. The article continues:
Mr Barratt said he had replied "well Max, people have to make choices. If I am to be put out to grass then the grass will have to be lush.
This is the farce we have in Defence at the moment. The minister is so caught up with worrying about his departmental head and giving him the flick that he cannot concentrate on the most important issues.
What are the important issues? Firstly, there was the birthday bash at the barracks for the Prime Minister. That was a big event. He had to worry about that because the minister trotted along with a few invited guests. We all remember this photo.
—Look at the fur!
—Never mind the fur—he is illegal. Why? He is not wearing a seatbelt. He is in a Comcar and he is not wearing a seatbelt. That is against the law. Bob Hawke got into trouble over that. Will this minister? Maybe. But the other issues of concern in Defence at the present time run seriously and they run deep.
With the Defence Reform Program, this minister is oversighting, supposedly, savings of $1 billion to be directed to the pointy end of Defence. What has he got so far? He has a force structure that nobody quite knows what it will end up at. People are bailing out left, right and centre. Why? They are unhappy, morale is low and then this government sticks a fringe benefits tax requirement on them.
—He didn't know that.
—We have asked questions about it. I have to say that the shadow minister for industrial relations is dead right. I do not think that until yesterday the minister 
 knew anything about the fringe benefits tax and the effect it had on the 43½ thousand—or nearly 50,000 now, but they want to get it down to 43½ thousand—serving defence men and women. He had no idea about the effect that might have.
This minister has elevated a second brigade to 28-day readiness so that we have two such brigades. The money required for that—at least $200 million a year to keep it ready—is fine if we need it, but with the savings that are supposed to come from the Defence Reform Program that are not happening they are not redirecting that money anywhere. As we pointed out twice in the last two days, surgical teams are trying to provide capability—and Major General Hartley has commented on what that means.
The Prime Minister has made a commitment on FBT that no group would be worse off under any of the changed tax regime introducing the GST. This minister should know something about the present strategic environment that is out there. We know he has been to Bali with the Prime Minister to talk with the Indonesians, but I seriously wonder if he has turned his attention to things that are required in the strategic review that is under way that will lead to a white paper. The strategic review will be secret; the white paper will be published next year. When the last strategic review came out, two weeks later the Asian economy crashed and yet that strategic review did not even pick it. That had an effect on Australia's capability and the acquisition we need in terms of replacement of the platform for the Australian Defence Force to do what it is supposed to do—defend Australia—and decisions were being made on false premises coming out of that document.
There are also the questions of East Timor and ongoing peacekeeping arrangements in Bougainville. There is the question of continuing defence support for Papua New Guinea. Comments are being made about the minister not knowing that his department is generating intelligence reports and passing them on to Alexander Downer's foreign affairs department—and I bet he does not read them, and if he did he would not know what was in them—and telling them all about 
 Indonesia and East Timor. That is military intelligence coming in that this minister does not know anything about. He then jumps up and down and says, `Oh, don't do that again! Don't do that without telling me! And you're not going to give any of those military secrets away without telling me!'
Who is running that department? When we start to talk about things like block obsolescence—that is, when we need to replace destroyers, F18s, F111s, patrol boats and all those things—who is going to make decisions on this? Not the Minister for Defence—the absent Minister for Defence who is not even here to answer the charge. He cannot concentrate because he is too worried about sacking Mr Barratt and trying to work out which option he should take.
We actually know. The way things are going there is another problem coming for him. We have already seen this. A couple of weeks ago, the minister proudly announced to all and sundry that a $2 billion contract for the new airborne early warning system has just been let to Boeing. What do we find out today? Boeing is being investigated by the United States Congress because it might be giving away secrets. We are in a partnership with the US and yet that arrangement is being investigated by the Congress to see how many of their secrets are being given away. This minister is presiding over $2 billion worth of public expenditure on some platform that we need. However, now questions are being raised over how successful that is likely to be and whether we are going to get all the information we need.
We could also talk about Olympic security or the reserves. If this minister actually got out of the Bushmasters or the photo opportunities being provided on the FFGs or something else and talked to his personnel, he would know that they are concerned about the future of the reserves in this country. People are not prepared to sign up anymore. The need for the reserves to be part of the general defence of this nation is increasing. As we keep raising our preparedness, as we keep increasing the availability of highly trained personnel to participate in all sorts of activities in our region, there is a strategic vacuum. 
 There is a lack of regional leadership coming from this minister and, as a consequence, our international reputation is going through the floor.
This minister needs to do more than simply stand there taking salutes at base visits. He needs to be accountable. He needs to be responsible. He is required by the normal standards of this parliament to come into this place and provide answers to genuine questions being put to him by members of the opposition or to respond to newspaper commentary that even his own department's newspapers are putting out. Army and Navy publications are both raising issues about FBT and other concerns that they have at the moment.
And these are government controlled authorities—a bit like the old Soviet bloc, but they are even allowing letters to be published saying that the FBT impact is just horrendous. We have the office of the revolution in military affairs, which I have said also sounds a bit Stalinist, but that has been created in the department. That is fine, because it has a job that it is going to do. But I have to say that this minister is not doing his job. Yesterday in question time when a question was put to the Prime Minister about the confidence of the ADF in this minister, the Prime Minister after a glib response turned to the Minister for Defence and said, `You owe me a case of Grange for that.' The Minister for Foreign Affairs said, `It would be cheaper if you just resigned.' Dead right! As Barratt said:
The problem with John Moore is that he does not do his homework and he will not listen.
That was reported in the Courier-Mail  on the seventh of this month. It is time not for Mr Barratt to go but for the Minister for Defence, who is on his last tour of duty, to probably think about taking the Wellington or the Paris option himself. This afternoon, though, it is time for this minister to come into this House to explain himself and to defend his handling of his department.

name: Hawker, David, MP
text:
—I have heard some pretty woeful presentations here, but that one really takes the cake. This afternoon I have been sitting here waiting to hear something of substance, but where is it? 
 It seems that the member for Cunningham could not even remember what the topic of the MPI was; he never once mentioned the topic. He got up and spoke for 15 minutes and could not even remember what he had decided was going to be the topic for the MPI.
But it gets worse than that. Let us go back to question time. We sat there waiting, thinking he was going to get on to defence, but it took 15 questions before the member for Cunningham could ask a question on defence. It is amazing. It is such an important issue that he cannot remember what his matter of public importance is about and he cannot even get a question up until the 15th question in question time today. When we look at the quality of the questions he put up it is no wonder he was so low down on the list. In the first question he tried to misrepresent the minister's answer from yesterday. If he does not believe me he can check the Hansard; he ought to have read properly what the minister's answer was yesterday before he tried to misrepresent it. When he got the next call his silly question asked the minister to tell him what happened in cabinet. Really and truly, he has been around a bit longer than that. If he was going to ask a serious question he would not be asking that sort of question.
The member for Cunningham then went on to ask some silly questions of the Minister for Trade. His last question rehashed a subject he had brought up yesterday—nothing of substance about defence or the importance of defence for this nation. Yet it is rather curious that, in the course of his address, he did admit at one stage—I do not think he meant to—that this minister has increased the state of the Defence Force's preparedness. In other words, serious things are happening, very important things are happening, and this government is really making them happen. Yet the member was so busy talking about the gloss and all the little newspaper reports he wanted to read that he never got into any substance about the importance of the defence of Australia and the fact that this government not only has a very good policy but also is implementing that policy.
It was just amazing that the member for Cunningham got up and read a newspaper article. It was suburban theatre antics. If that is all he can do—read a newspaper article and try to put all these wonderful theatrics in it—it is not a very effective presentation. You would have to say that it was a very superficial effort and one that his colleagues would be very disappointed with. If this is the best that the opposition in the parliament of Australia can do it is not only a great disappointment to the people of Australia but also an insult to Defence personnel, this parliament and the people of Australia.
We ought to get real. More than just talking and having these ideas rolling off the tongue—all the right words about the various things that are happening in Defence but never getting into substance—we really have to look at some of the important things. To get the record going properly, I will read from the newsletter that the Minister for Defence—the person that I think we are trying to talk about—issued in June 1999. In an `Overview of Australia's defence priorities' he says:
The defence of Australia has been a major priority of the Howard Government and continues to be so during our second term.
I say, `Hear, hear,' and anyone who has any interest in defence would fully agree with that. He goes on to say:
We are strongly committed to building a stronger and more secure Australia.
Again, that is what Australians want and expect and what Australians are getting. The article continues:
An Australia that is able to defend itself and able to take its place confidently in an uncertain world.
It is important to note those words. He goes on to say:
The government takes the challenge of rebuilding the nation's Defence capability just as seriously as it took the challenge of rebuilding the economy.
Note the word `rebuilding'—not `building'—because of some of the difficulties and problems we inherited from the previous Labor government. He goes on to say:
In fact, the Defence budget has been maintained in real terms for four years now— 

There have been no cuts like under the previous government; we have actually maintained the budget in real terms—
and we propose to continue this level of commitment through the life of the forward estimates in this year's Budget.
Also, as the minister goes on to say in his newsletter:
We also are committed to obtaining the greatest value possible for each Defence dollar spent.
This is when we start to get serious about what this government is on about. We should make no apologies for the fact that this government not only expects high standards but it insists on high standards and insists that they be met in the defence department and in any other area of administration, but we are particularly talking about Defence today.
These very high standards are expected to be met by staff in the department as well as those who are out in the combat areas. Frankly, the men and women in the field not only expect this but deserve it. They deserve nothing less than the highest of standards. I would have thought that any reasonable and, indeed, any responsible opposition would have supported these standards.
—We support the diggers, I can tell you.
—You ought to support a bit more. What about the high standards of the defence department? I think that the government has a very good record in the area of defence. It is one that we are very proud of and one that we are building on. Can I say that all of this in this term of parliament is due to the very good work being done by the Minister for Defence. The excellent work he is doing will mean that we have an even better defence effort than we already have.
When we talk about the ability of the Minister for Defence, we ought to actually recognise what he has done as a minister and, most importantly, what he is doing as the Minister for Defence. The first thing is that he has demonstrated since we have been in government that he is a man who gets results. That is very important. Given the importance of the defence of this country, we have to have a minister of this sort of calibre. Follow 
 ing some very good work done as the industry minister, he has now built on that as defence minister. One of the areas where the minister has really demonstrated his ability is in picking the best people to work with him. It is a very significant factor. It is something which many ministers on the other side who may have had ability often failed to do—to get people working with them and working for them who were the very best available. That is exactly what this minister can do. When I listen to some of the petty, nitpicking things that come from the opposition, I think they have completely overlooked this very significant fact.
The other point I would like to reinforce on the ability of the Minister for Defence is that he gets his portfolio issues through the cabinet. Again, that is a very significant thing. He then gets them through the government ranks and he gets them through the parliament. All of these are very important. When we look at things like the budget and when we look at the fact that the defence forces are now in a situation where the member for Cunningham admitted they are in a better state of preparedness, I think we have got to recognise that the minister has been doing that.
It is also important just to reflect a little bit on the legacy we inherited from Labor. The great concern that many people who really understand defence had about Labor is the drift that was going on in the defence forces through the lack of clear priorities. There is no doubt that the combat capability was declining. There is no doubt that the administration, the bureaucracy, was growing. Time and again we saw that equipment budgets were blowing out not only in cost but also on their time frame. When you look at all that and look at the number of times Labor let the defence forces down, and more significantly let the defence of Australia down, it is no wonder that people in Australia changed government. I think that in many ways it is a cheek of the opposition to come in here and try to raise this issue when they really have not got a lot to crow about in their own achievements.
When we look at the record on defence spending, what we see is that the spending 
 promises were always kept for defence expenditure whereas, on their promise to increase, only 23 per cent was ever delivered. When we look at the question of combat capability, we saw ships being fitted out for but not with equipment—so leaving gaps. In other words, the ships were there but there were a few things missing, and if it came to actual engagement they were a little light on. But Labor thought, `We can defer that because we can make budget cuts and it does not look too bad.' We look at the some of the mismanagement. There were a couple of rusty second-hand ships that cost us the earth because of all the money that had to be spent to bring them up to a serviceable standard. We saw what happened with the over-the-horizon radar. What a shambles, what an embarrassment. We hear people talking about cost blow-outs and we look at what that cost us. We look at the run-down in the Army capability. We look at the units that were lacking equipment. We look at the inefficiency that was growing. It just went on and on.
What was even more disturbing, certainly to those who had a keen interest in defence, was looking at Labor's 1998 election policy. You would think Labor might have learned something. Having been chucked out in 1996, they might have had a look and thought, `Defence is pretty important. We had better have a good look at it.' As someone put it unkindly, the policy for 1998 probably took 30 minutes to write, five minutes to read and about 30 seconds to dismiss. What were they going to do? First of all, they were going to have an Anzac battalion. It sounded all right, but they had forgotten something. The New Zealand defence minister, Mr Max Bradford, said, `Hey, whoa,' so that one disappeared. The next thing was that they wanted to cancel the upgrade of the Hornets. That might have saved them a bit of money, but it meant this great gap because we probably could not get a replacement in under 10 years. And if we did not upgrade them then what were we going to do—keep running aircraft that were more and more out of date? As I think the member for Cunningham would know, Australia's defence is very much based on the fact that we have to maintain a technological advantage in the region. That was the second 
 part of the election policy which disappeared without trace.
The third one was—this was a beauty—buy two more submarines. We all know the embarrassment with the submarines at the moment. They were going to buy a couple more. What about fixing up the ones we have already got? We have to admit that the state of preparedness of our submarines is a source of considerable embarrassment, particularly as the only operational submarine we have got is the old Oberon one. To keep that running, we have had to actually cannibalise parts out of one that is sitting in a park in Holbrook. It really is an embarrassment. I do not think the Labor Party would want to go into too much of the history of the Collins class submarines, because we know when those decisions were taken.
—You've been dealing with them for three years.
—It is important to note who is fixing them up. This government and this minister are taking the tough decisions to fix up the problem, and the problem will be fixed. As the honourable member for Cunningham would know, this report is very significant and it will be acted upon. So it is important to note that this government is going to make these things happen.
Labor were going to reinstate the Ready Reserve, but they did not quite say where they were going to get the money to run that. The last time they brought in the Ready Reserve, two battalions went west. Then they were going to build an offshore weapons range, but that was going to cost a heap of money, and we do not know where that money was coming from either. What that really said was that there was a lack of strategic vision and, listening to today's debate and the views put forward by the spokesman from the Labor Party, that strategic vision is still sadly lacking. It is sad because we are talking about something that is very important for Australia. It is very sad that defence, which is such an important issue for all Australians, should be reduced to this level by the opposition.
Clearly, we want to see defence forces that really have high standards. We are making 
 those standards. It is disappointing that the opposition will not support those efforts, but I am proud to be able to stand up here and say that this government and the Minister for Defence are really doing a first-class job in improving the standards of our Australian defence forces, improving their readiness and, most importantly, ensuring that the defence of Australia is being improved so that we can continue to live the lives that all of us so dearly want. (Time expired)

name: Snowdon, Warren, MP
text:
—Firstly, let me say to the member for Wannon that I am sorry you have been asked to carry the can for someone whom you need to apologise for. I say that because the men and women of the Australian defence forces should rightly expect that their minister should be in this chamber to respond to questions about his ministry and his administration of that ministry, yet he is not here. He has not even put in the junior minister. So on behalf of the opposition I say to the serving men and women of the Australian defence forces that I am sorry that the Minister for Defence has not got the gumption to come in here and defend himself and advocate his position as a defence minister.
I am also sorry for the member for Wannon because, pal, you were sold a dump. Your advocacy of the minister's position was what I thought it would be: half-hearted, not sincere and unable to be backed up with any legitimate arguments. After all, you had the gumption to actually say in your response that the minister had demonstrated that he got results. You then said he got portfolio issues through cabinet. I am very sorry, but I am not quite sure I understand what you were saying.
—It's irony.
—You are right. For the last couple of days we have been hearing a defence by this minister of an outrageous attack on the serving circumstances of defence personnel through the changes proposed in the fringe benefits tax. Yet until yesterday this minister was not even aware of the impact of those fringe benefits tax changes on his own personnel.
—Shame!
—That is shameful. When he responded to the question yesterday, what did he say? It is worth quoting his response:
. . . everyone will benefit from tax cuts. As a result of the tax cuts, many of the expenses that were referred to are well and truly covered.
I ask you: what person in Australia could possibly accept that this minister knows anything about what is going on in his portfolio, let alone about what passed through cabinet as part of the taxation proposals that recently passed through this parliament? He did not even understand the implications of the tax package on the standards of his own personnel—50,000 serving men and women in this country.
—Where is he now?
—Why won't he come into this place? Why won't he come and defend himself? I say to the member for Longman, who I understand is speaking next, that you were a serving officer; you understand the importance of these things to Defence Force personnel.
—The member for the Northern Territory will address his remarks through the chair.
—He will understand, Mr Deputy Speaker, that his former colleagues in the defence forces are standing back and saying, `We have lost respect for this minister. He is a shame on this government. We have lost respect because his lack of leadership. We have lost respect because of his lack of understanding. We have lost respect because of his lack of authority. We have lost respect because of his lack of sincerity. We have lost respect because of his lack of intelligence, because the bloke's a dill.'
—And where is the dill?
—Where is he? I say to the member for Longman: when you get out of here this afternoon, go and ring some of your former colleagues and ask them what they think of the performance of this minister. Ask them what they think of the performance of this government. Ask them what they think of the proposals on the fringe benefits tax. Ask them what they think of the threats to 
 their lives and lifestyles as a result of these proposals. I have to say to the member for Longman and to the member for Wannon—and I am not quite sure what the simile is but there must be one—that you have been given the greatest dump on earth. Not even you have any respect for this minister.
—Cannon fodder.
—Is that the description I am looking for? You are absolutely cannon fodder. I do not know if there is any promotion in it for you, but I have to tell you there is a vacancy coming up soon. He has gone AWOL, he is not in here to defend himself and he is not here to advocate his position.
—Give us substance.
—You want to hear about substance. I will tell you a bit about substance: this minister is incompetent. I have been a member of this parliament off and on for 10 years and I can say to you that the concerns being expressed by the defence forces about the malaise in the Department of Defence and the lack of leadership by this minister are unprecedented.
I have had representations from personnel from all three forces, from every rank, expressing their concern about the lack of leadership of this minister—his lack of authority, his lack of knowledge, his lack of commitment and his lack of understanding of the strategic imperatives of the Defence Force. He does not know, does not care and does not understand. Defence staff are rightly upset at the wiping out of benefits that compensate them for the unique hardships and transient nature of service life. We are not talking about lurks and perks here—and you know we are not talking about lurks and perks. We are simply talking about the benefits that help families survive while they are doing their jobs. The Top End is a focal point for Australia's defence strategy, and already it is extremely difficult to recruit qualified personnel and to attract ADF families there.
We have heard about the specialist surgeons. We have a 28-day ready for 1 Brigade in Darwin. Possibly they are going to be deployed somewhere or other in the near future—or possibly in the longer term. But, if 
 they are deployed tomorrow, they cannot take a medical team because there is no—
—Rubbish.
—`Rubbish,' he says. I can tell you it is not rubbish. They would not be able to take a medical team because there is not one currently available. The minister acknowledged as much here in this House yesterday.
I have had serving personnel come to see me about this, and I have to say to you that they are concerned by the perfidy of this minister who has a responsibility to represent and reflect the needs of these 50,000 Australians. He has failed to represent their interests in cabinet, contrary to what the member for Wannon has said. He has failed, either as a direct result of indolence, ignorance or malevolence, to comprehend the tragic and negative impact of his own government's policy on ADF personnel.
The morale of the ADF is being continually and severely undermined by his incompetence and by the implications of the ineptitude of the minister and the Howard government in coming to terms with the inevitable operational impacts of their absurd policies. Do they comprehend that separation rates from the defence forces will magnify by 10 or a hundredfold? Thousands of defence personnel have indicated they will leave the defence forces if this FBT thing is not fixed. What will that do to the operational readiness of the Australian Defence Force? It will wreck it. What capacity will we then have to recruit new people to come and fill their roles? What possibilities will we have to recruit those people in time to train them up to the operational standards that you, as a former serving officer, would require of them? You know, I know, that we are right. The minister has been totally irresponsible.
—Where is he?
—He is not here. We ask that question again: where is he? Why isn't he here? Why is he AWOL? Why doesn't he come here? Because he is worried about his preselection for the seat of Ryan. He knows there are 150 new people on the branch books in Ryan ready to roll him. So, instead of 
 being occupied by his job as Minister for Defence, he is preoccupied by the branch stacking in his own electorate which is designed to knock him off. Do you know what I say to those branch stackers? I say, `Good on you. Get rid of the bloke because he is an incompetent.' He is an absolute incompetent, and it is about time the Prime Minister took his role seriously as the leader of this government, as the erstwhile leader of this nation—erstwhile responsible for oversighting the work of the Minister for Defence. Why doesn't he pull him into order? Why doesn't he pull him into line? Why doesn't he send him into this chamber to make sure that he defends himself? Because of that, I move:
That so much of the standing and sessional orders be suspended as will prevent the sitting being suspended until the Minister for Defence is in attendance so that he may respond to the serious matters concerning his administration which have been raised during this discussion.
Motion (by Mr Williams) proposed:
That the member be not further heard.
The bells being rung—
—Mr Deputy Speaker, on a point of order: is it in order for a silly minister to move that the member be no longer heard when his time has run out?
—Order! There is no point of order. The honourable member had moved the motion.
Question put.
The House divided.				[4.07 p.m.]

name: Brough, Mal, MP
text:
—Don't go running out of the chamber; you might learn something.
Mr Martin interjecting—
—You are just trying to delay the process because you are afraid of hearing some substance—the only bit of substance we would have heard after 25 minutes of rabblerousing by you lot.
Let us just answer some of the questions that have been put here this afternoon. The first one is about medical officers and their availability. The charge has been that, if the 1 Brigade, which is based in Darwin, had to go overseas tomorrow, they would not be able to take a medical team with them. I am advised that the Chief of the Defence Force says that the ADF has an appropriate medical 
 capacity to support the ADF deployment in regional contingencies. So if the Chief of the Defence Force says that, where do you lot get your information from? From the back of newspapers as always. You do not actually deal with any facts. You deal with rhetoric and rubbish, and it is about time you dealt with facts. There are enough medical facilities and medical staff for the defence forces.
For the benefit of the member for the Northern Territory, I was a serving officer. I served with 2/4 RAR in Townsville. Do you know what we had as a medical officer under a Labor government? We had a gynaecologist. Do you know how many women there are in 2/4 Royal Australian Regiment? Zero—not one. But the Labor government administration saw fit to provide us with a gynaecologist. A really top effort. Well done. Congratulations to Beazley and his mates who were of course running the show then. That is how much the Labor Party know about the medical profession and what is needed. I will let you in on a little secret: there are not too many infantry soldiers in our Army that actually get pregnant.
Now let us move on to Boeing and the announcement that the minister made recently about the AEWACs. On 10 August, an article appeared in the Sydney Morning Herald—it is good to see that you are up on your literacy and can actually read—which suggested that Boeing had a problem with the American Defence Department. I can assure you that, as far as this government is concerned and the contract that we have entered into, there will be no problem whatsoever in delivering those services to Australia. That is what should be important to the opposition, to the wider community and the defence forces. Those aircraft will provide a very much needed capacity for Australia's defence. The matter of public importance today is about substance, and all we have had is rhetoric from those opposite. We have had nothing about our capacity to be able to defend our nation, which is what the defence forces are supposed to be about.
Yesterday, the Leader of the Opposition asked a question. He said, `. . . at a time when the government has just doubled the 
 size of ADF units on 28-days combat alert.' This minister announced that, by 1 July this year, the Australian Defence Force would be able to double its capacity for ready, alert soldiers. In other words, 1 Brigade in Darwin was going to be brought up to 28-day readiness. I thought at the time that that was a very ambitious task.
I was in 1 Brigade back in 1979 when we decided to bring 3 Brigade up to such a standard, and it is exceptionally difficult to do. A good friend of mine is currently the commanding officer of the 5th/7th Battalion and, as the minister has already informed this House—and I am pleased to reiterate—that they have managed to do that and it means that Australia's Defence Force capacity has been greatly boosted. That did not happen by accident. That did not happen under 13 years of Labor. That happened under the member for Ryan, the Minister for Defence, in this Howard government. That is what managing defence and administration is all about: having combat forces that are able to meet the defence needs of this nation.
I have just mentioned that we do have the medical forces that are necessary—the MOs—and we have the new Boeings coming on line for the AWACs. Now we can talk about the Defence Reform Program. The shadow minister stated in his address earlier on that he did not know where the savings were going to come from. In this financial year, 1999-2000, it was forecast that there would be a $455 million saving to defence which could go into the sharp end—that is, people who actually carry weapons and actually make a difference at the front. In fact, we will be $67 million ahead of that plan. They are the facts—unlike the rhetoric and rubbish that we cop from the other side.
The shadow minister also said that there were no cuts to defence under the previous Labor government. I questioned him across the chamber. I said, `No cuts?' and he said, `No, not one; none at all.' The fact is that whilst they were in government, they promised growth in defence spending of 4.5 per cent in 1984-85 but they did not deliver it; in 1985-86, again 4.5 per cent but they did not 
 deliver it; and 3.8 per cent in 1986-87, but they did not deliver it.
—Just have a look at the real growth.
—They did not deliver it. It is like me saying to you, `We're going to give you some extra money to buy capability next year, the year after and the year after that,' and then you make plans to train your soldiers so that they are at the highest levels of competency and then, when in government, you let them down. You pulled the rug out from under their feet. You did not just do it for one year; you did it right through from 1984 to 1991. In 1991, you promised two per cent and again you provided zero, zilch, nothing—not a cent. That is the sort of commitment that the Labor Party showed Defence in 13 years. You can shake your head all you like—the facts are there.
I was actually a serving member of the defence forces from 1979 through 1988. I had to endure the disgusting depletion of our resources by the Labor Party. We had a situation where you have two men to train 10 soldiers to use two machine guns—two M60s, which quite often went off when they were not supposed to because they were that badly worn. And you talk about morale! That is what sends morale down the tubes—when soldiers are not game to point the rifle in the right direction because they are not sure whether it is going to go off at the right time.
Let us get to the major programs. JORN is an over-the-horizon radar. It has allowed us to detect movement in the sea-air gap to our north. It was a brilliant piece of strategic thinking. Let us look at the administration, since this is what this matter of public importance is about. When over 80 per cent of the money was paid out in that contract, it would be logical to presume that you would have about 80 per cent of the product delivered. Not under the Labor Party. Under the Labor Party, around 25 per cent of the product was delivered for an 80 per cent cost. And did it work? No; it did not even work. What do those opposite have to say now? They have all gone awfully flaming quiet, haven't they? They go quiet when they get something of substance thrown back at them about what 
 their incompetence did to the Australian defence forces and our capacity as a nation to defend ourselves.
Let us turn to submarines. The submarine saga has been going on for many years. Let me just talk about the combat system, since we have only a couple of minutes left. I will quote from a report entitled Report to the Minister for Defence on the Collins class submarine and related matters. At page 10 it states:
The combat system is at the heart of the issues associated with getting an overall favourable outcome for the Submarine Project.
It goes on to say:
Although known about earlier, the problem was first seriously highlighted in 1993—
when the Labor Party was in government—
but the opportunity was not then taken to make fundamental changes in the configuration of the system or in the choice of subcontractor.
The report goes on to say that this litany of errors and poor administration basically led to the fact that today Australia has such a poor submarine capacity that, if it were needed to send off the submarines, the lives of our submariners would be put in danger. As a former defence member, I find that a deplorable state over which the Leader of the Opposition should hang his head in shame.
I have already mentioned that 1 Brigade is now on 28 days notice to move. That has happened under this government. Over and above that, when we mentioned that we do have enough medical support to be able to support these troops should they go to Asia, those opposite said, `We did a strategic paper and two weeks later the Asian crisis occurred. Boy, why didn't they see it coming?' I did not hear anybody in the opposition saying they saw it coming. I did not hear anybody in the world—in the financial markets, the defence markets or anywhere else—saying they saw it coming. This government has ensured that our defence capabilities are able to meet the needs as they change more rapidly in the region. The defence white paper, which will go a long way to addressing our preparations beyond the year 2000, will also be supplemented with an increase in the frequency of internal strategic assessments. So per 
 haps things such as the Asian crisis can be picked up.
Finally, I turn to the F18s. We have talked about the submarines. Today we have virtually no capability because of the inefficiency and poor administration of Beazley and those opposite. His policy at the last election was to replace the F18 with a new aircraft, which would take some 10 years. That means that we would have no capability for those fighter jets either. Great! Let's not have anything in the water; let's not have anything in the sky; let's pillory those who have made sure that 1 Brigade is now operational; let's not have a defence force at all. If you did that you would do in the future what Gough Whitlam tried to do back in the 1970s. The defence minister is delivering for Australia and for Australia's defence. He has the full support of this government. He is delivering on our policies to the defence forces. Australia's Defence Force will remain a strong, viable force when you, the opposition, support us in government.(Time expired)

name: Rudd, Kevin, MP
text:
—I support the honourable member for Cunningham in proposing this subject as a matter of public importance. The defence of Australia goes to the heart of the core policy interests of the nation. When we look at the resources which are dedicated to the ADF each year and at a budget which extends to $15 billion per year, we are required to answer this very basic question: how can we allow this parliament to produce such a minister who is responsible for such a critical area as the defence of the nation?
The defence policy of this country has been treated to a number of serious policy reviews over the last 10 to 15 years. When Mr Beazley was defence minister in the Labor government, we had a period of intellectual ferment and policy review across the defence portfolio such as we had not seen in the history of Australian defence policy. When we look back at the Dibb review of Australian defence and the strategic bases document which emerged from the Dibb review, at the definition of the area of direct military interest which emerged from that review and at the definition of Australia's area of strategic 
 interest beyond immediate South-East Asia and across into the South China Sea and beyond, we find that we had, for the first time, a clinical definition of where Australia's defence interests lay. Contrary to what the previous speaker, the member for Longman, said, what emerged was a sophisticated defence policy on which we could construct a force structure for the defence of Australia for the first time. The Dibb review outlined a way in which we could engage in a layered defence of the nation which began from—

name: Lee, Michael, MP
text:
—Before I commence my remarks on the Employment, Education and Training Amendment Bill 1999 , I acknowledge the presence in the upper gallery of students and teachers from Brooke Avenue Public School in my electorate, who I am sure, like all of us, are very interested in matters affecting education in Australia.
This bill abolishes the National Board of Employment, Education and Training, commonly known as NBEET, along with the Australian Language and Literacy Council, the Employment and Skills Council, the Higher Education Council and the Schools Council. It retains the Australian Research Council, although we were advised in the long awaited research green paper that the government wants to establish the ARC under its own act. We can be grateful for some small mercies because in the earlier drafts of the research green paper that were leaked late last year there was some doubt about what role the ARC would be left with. There was also some suggestion that the entire peer review process for awarding research grants would be completely undermined. We welcome the fact that the initial proposals by the Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs have been dumped by the government and we look forward to the ARC being placed on a firm footing under its own act.
NBEET was established in 1988 to provide advice to the government on issues relating to education and training as a unified advisory mechanism outside the department. It was seen as an important component of the program of reform in employment, education and training. The then minister, John Dawkins, told the House of Representatives during the second reading of the legislation establishing NBEET:
The central purpose of this Bill is to enhance and streamline advisory structures in employment, 
 education and training in a manner consistent with the high economic and social priority placed on these activities by the government.
Unlike the Hawke and Keating governments, the Howard government has given no priority whatsoever to education and training issues. In that sense, it is no surprise that the Howard government would regard a body like NBEET as being a target for termination. NBEET initially comprised a board to report directly to the minister, and four advisory councils: the Australian Research Council, the Employment and Skills Formation Council, the Higher Education Council and the Schools Council. In 1995, the Australian Language and Literacy Council was added to the structure, while the Australian International Education Foundation Council is in fact a committee of the board. Neither the board nor its councils have had any program delivery role, unlike previous advisory structures such as the Tertiary Education Commission and the Schools Commission. The Australian Research Council, however, makes recommendations about the allocation of research funds.
A specific value of NBEET lay in its ability to examine issues on a cross-sectoral basis, at a time when the traditional barriers separating schools, vocational education, higher education and labour market programs were being pulled down. The direction of recent discussions on such issues all seek to reinforce the importance of developing cross-sectoral perspectives. Let me give four examples: firstly, the convergence of general and vocational education; secondly, the nature and importance of employment related key competencies, articulation, credit transfer and recognition of prior learning both within and between sectors; thirdly, how to enable people to follow `pathways' through different parts of education and training institutions to achieve the combination of skills and knowledge which they need; and, fourthly, the emergence of the often discussed concept of lifelong learning. All of these examples serve to reinforce the importance of developing and receiving cross-sectoral advice to the government.
The revolution in methods and technologies for delivering education and training is also contributing to the blurring of traditional 
 divisions. Final year high school students can now undertake university studies as part of their school program, while many vocational courses can now be or will be able to be delivered in workplaces and schools, rather than only in TAFE colleges. I recently had the privilege of visiting Casuarina Senior College in Darwin. It is great to see the number of course options which students at that college are now able to choose. It is a fascinating example of a school which is making sure that the resources it has built up over many years are available not only to the students but also to the parents at night, thus ensuring that adult education is advanced in their local community.
The issue of the need for cross-sectoral perspectives was taken up in submissions to the Senate inquiry into this bill's predecessor—the government's first attempt to abolish NBEET—the Employment, Education and Training Amendment Bill 1996, which never completed its passage through the parliament. In a submission to that inquiry, Professor lan Chubb, Vice-Chancellor of Flinders University and a former Deputy Chair of NBEET, said:
If some relationship between employment, education and training is assumed, then I believe a minister will need some body or other to integrate the often conflicting advice that will come from the various interest groups and to turn it into policy advice.
Professor Chubb went on to say:
I have seen no good reason put forward for the abolition of NBEET.
Nor has the opposition seen any good reason put forward for the abolition of NBEET. Mr Peter Laver, a former chairman of NBEET, told the Senate inquiry:
One of the benefits of the national board's structure has been the confederation style, where six councils basically report through a board to the Minister. This means that the implications of various pieces of advice are fully considered by putting it through the board so that the cross-sectoral aspects are accommodated prior to the advice being forwarded to the Minister and tabled in Parliament.
Mr Laver also said:
The other thing that I would have to say about the board is that in terms of providing advice—I have been associated with other government advisory 
 bodies in the manufacturing industry and in science and technology and in rural areas—NBEET is quite a cost-effective way of doing it. The cost of running the national board compared to its output is a pretty good investment.
Mr Laver's views about the effectiveness of NBEET were shared by Professor Ken Wiltshire, who conducted the review of the board, which reported in February 1994. The report concluded:
It can reasonably be stated that NBEET has fulfilled the bulk of the high expectations which were held for it six years ago.
The executive summary of the Wiltshire review talks in the following way about the changes facing Australia:
We still do not have, in this country, a clear enough understanding of, and a better capacity to address, the crucial linkages between the nation's economic performance, its employment parameters, and the implications for the role of the education and training sectors.
These challenges face all nations in the approach to the next century and millennium, but Australia is better positioned than most, with a portfolio grouping aligned to these dominant themes, and an independent body capable of marshalling the requisite knowledge and expertise . . . 
Again quoting from the executive summary of the Wiltshire review:
The themes which should be the challenge for NBEET in its second era are intersectoral and international, for it will be policy advice of this kind on which Australia will depend and which any vision of this nation's future will encompass.
In the face of this advice from the Wiltshire review, the coalition took to the 1996 election a policy to dismantle NBEET, with no reasons given and, more importantly, no structure to replace it. One of the first things the Howard government did on coming to office was to prepare legislation to cut itself off from independent advice from a body with almost a decade of corporate knowledge about the importance of linking together employment, education and training issues. The 1996 legislation, however, retained the Higher Education Council, whose role it has been to provide considered advice to the government through the board on directions, priorities and funding issues related to higher education.
The Higher Education Council also had the important responsibility of monitoring the 
 impact of HECS—the Higher Education Contribution Scheme—on participation in university education. It has done this through a series of reports tabled in parliament. In its sixth such report, published in March 1992, the NBEET board said:
The Board noted the results of the Council's commissioned research on the impact of HECS on the participation of disadvantaged groups in higher education.
The Council has concluded from the research that HECS [as it was in 1991], has little effect on the decision of the educationally disadvantaged groups identified in the research.
So in 1991, the research which NBEET had carried out, the work carried out by the Higher Education Council, indicated that HECS, as previously introduced by the former Labor government, had little effect on the decision of the educationally disadvantaged to participate in higher education. The educationally disadvantaged groups examined in the council's research included students from low socioeconomic backgrounds, rural students, students from non-English speaking backgrounds indigenous students and single parents.
It is interesting to compare the advice provided in March 1992 to the 12th and most recent such report from the Higher Education Council, which looked at outcomes for 1996 and 1997. The report lists the coalition's major cuts and changes to higher education, which were announced in 1996. It states:
Clearly, issues such as these are beyond the scope of this report on 1997 activity, but will be covered in future years.
This is the advice that was provided in 1996. Let me repeat that:
Clearly, issues such as these—
that is, the cuts that this government made in funding for universities and the increases in HECS—
are beyond the scope of this report on 1997 activity, but will be covered in future years.
If this bill is passed, these issues will not be examined—an outcome for which the coalition may well have cause to be grateful, because the information we have to date about the impact of increased HECS charges and a radically reduced repayment threshold 
 is that these changes have significantly impacted on participation in higher education. Australia-wide, applications for enrolment have fallen by 3.3 per cent in 1997, and a further 2.7 per cent in 1998. This year, they have recovered slightly but are still 4.8 per cent below the level of 1996. And that is overall, with no information about specific groups such as those included in the Higher Education Council's surveys.
So it is no wonder that the Howard government wants to kill off the Higher Education Council before it has a chance to deliver the bad news: the information that we need to know how much damage has been done by this government's cuts in funding to higher education, by this government's increases in the charges for university students, by this government's decision to lower the repayment thresholds for people who build up a HECS debt. That is why this government wants to stop the Higher Education Council delivering any bad news in the form of detailed information about the extent of the damage done to access and equity in higher education in Australia.
The council's commissioned report, The effects of the introduction of fee-paying postgraduate courses on access for designated groups, published in 1997, concluded that fees do have a deterrent effect on postgraduate enrolment by some equity groups, pushing them towards HECS based enrolment. Under the Labor government, fee paying postgraduate places were balanced by broad availability of HECS places as well. This has changed completely under the coalition, with a fall of around 40 per cent in Commonwealth funded postgraduate course-work places, as a direct result of the coalition's $840 million cuts to university operating grants.
The 1997 Higher Education Council report also raised the issue of cuts to university operating grants, noting that, to the extent that universities have fewer resources, they have less capacity to undertake measures to improve equity and access. Since that report, universities have felt the impact of the major funding cuts announced by the Howard government in 1996.
Late last year, the Higher Education Council finalised a further report on postgraduate access in the new environment of vastly expanded fee paying. For some reason, that report has not even been published. It has, in fact, disappeared without trace—further evidence, if any were needed, that this government is determined to shut itself off from information about the impact of its short-sighted, damaging policies and to deny the community the benefit of independent evidence of the damage this government has done in higher education. More broadly, this is a government that is totally closed to new ideas. We now have a federal minister for education whose contribution to policy development has been zero, whose efforts have been concentrated on implementing a narrow ideological agenda, but who is unwilling to visit a university campus, and who steadfastly avoids contact with education interest groups and spokespeople who might challenge his views or provide a different perspective.
Unfortunately, the most recent budget—despite being labelled an education budget by the Prime Minister—was yet another lost opportunity and another demonstration of the government's failure to comprehend the fundamental importance of education and training. The government's so-called education budget concentrates additional school funding disproportionately in the non-government school sector—talking about need while ignoring the clear needs of government schools—and yet it makes yet another attack on higher education, axing the Merit Based Equity Scholarships Scheme and cutting $16 million from the Innovation Program. For TAFE there is nothing.
So in a budget that the Prime Minister claimed would be an education budget we have the abolition of the Merit Based Equity Scholarships Scheme, we have the latest cut in the operating grants for universities and we have no resumption of growth for TAFE. We have a government that does not provide a significant increase for funding for public schools while providing a substantial increase in federal funding for non-government schools. My real worry is that the Prime Minister might actually think an education 
 budget is when you give a massive increase in funding to non-government schools—an increase which is 21 times, on average, that given to students at government schools. How can government members sit back knowing that, for every extra dollar that went to students, teachers and staff at government schools, $21 went to students in non-government schools? Labor make it clear that we support extra funding going to needy private schools; we support extra funding going to improve the quality of education in non-government schools. But we have to balance that by providing not only significant increases in funding for private schools but also significant increases in funding for public schools.
—We did.
—The member interjects and claims that there was an increase.
—It will increase with the GST.
—The member interjects and claims that a GST will deliver a significant increase in funding to public schools. I simply suggest to the honourable member that he talk to the teachers and to the staff at schools in government schools in his own electorate to know that the GST is not going to be the answer to schools' difficulties in funding. In many cases, the GST will create an enormous additional administrative burden on schools right round Australia, be they public or private. It is the honourable member who will have to answer to the parents of children at his own local schools—government and private—who will be hit by the lost income that gets spent    on implementing the GST in schools in his own electorate. So my real concern is that this Prime Minister might actually think that an education budget is a budget that continues cuts in federal funding for universities across the country, that fails to deliver any growth funding for TAFE, that abolishes the Merit Based Equity Scholarships Scheme for disadvantaged young kids, that does not provide the balance in extra funding for government schools and non-government schools.
So these decisions prove the government has greater need than ever before of advice 
 from a body like NBEET, because improving children's opportunities at some schools while reducing access to vocational and higher education reflects a blinkered, distorted view of educational experience. Lifelong learning and a properly educated and skilled population begin with quality schooling, followed by access to well-resourced post-compulsory education and training institutions.
A sensible government understands the interaction between the sectors and the need for articulated pathways. Through this bill, the Howard government has shown us that not only does it not understand the concept of linkages but also that it does not want to understand, it does not want to listen, it does not want to know. As far as NBEET is concerned, the damage is done. The corporate knowledge has been largely scattered; the personnel have dispersed; and the board exists practically only in name.
Soon after the coalition came to office, the predecessor of the present Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs wrote an extremely ungracious letter to the Chairman of NBEET, setting out arrangements for the winding up of the board. That letter failed to acknowledge that NBEET had achieved anything. We believe this government has a record of seeking to silence independent organisations that disagree with government policy. I have to say that this government will be the worse for the loss of that independent advice. Therefore, I move the following second reading amendment:
That all words after "That" be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
"whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House:
(1)	 is of the opinion that education and training are of fundamental importance to Australia's social and economic well-being;
(2)	 notes that many of the emerging issues in employment, education and training are cross-sectoral in nature;
(3)	 expresses great concern that the body charged with providing independent, cross-sectoral advice to government on these significant issues has been dismantled by the Government;
(4)	 calls on the Government to establish immediately an independent review of the impact of 
 its changes to the Higher Education Contribution Scheme, one of the roles previously undertaken by the Higher Education Council; and
(5)	 notes the commitment of the Australian Labor Party, when returned to government, to re-establish a structure to provide independent, cross-sectoral advice on education and training".
—Is the amendment seconded?
—I second the amendment.

name: Nelson, Dr Brendan, MP
text:
—I rise to speak in support of the original Employment, Education and Training Amendment Bill 1999 , not the amendment moved by the member for Dobell. The bill seeks to do a number of things. As the member for Dobell correctly pointed out, it seeks to abolish the National Board of Employment, Education and Training and its subsidiary councils—these being the Australian Language and Literacy Council, the Employment and Skills Council, the Schools Council and the Higher Education Council. In 1987, under the chairmanship of Charles Holton, a task force report delivered to the then Minister for Employment, Education and Training, John Dawkins, recommended that there be a rationalisation of advisory structures in the employment portfolio. It has nothing to do with not understanding or not wanting to understand higher education or anything of the sort, as we have just heard.
One consequence of the establishment of the National Board of Employment, Education and Training was a loss of what were seen to be the positive attributes of the Schools Commission and the Tertiary Education Commission, from whose abolition it emerged. Firstly, their membership was largely representative of the sectors with which they dealt. Secondly, they were responsible for program administration and, consequently, had larger staffs and a greater capacity to set their own research and reporting agendas. Thirdly, the statutory conditions under which they operated had given them greater scope for independent action.
Governments of the day—and at the time, federally, that was a Labor government—and ministers in particular sought advice which 
 bore some relation to budgetary strategy, as any responsible government would. The new advisory arrangements were established by the Employment, Education and Training Act 1988. The critical features of the act were: firstly, a national board to report directly to the minister on all related employment, education and training issues, taking into account any written directions or guidelines from the minister on the government's broad social, economic and budgetary policies; secondly, four advisory councils would report to the board; thirdly, the new board would have no responsibility for program delivery, which would be left entirely to the department; and, fourthly, community based membership of the board and councils.
The Employment, Education and Training Amendment Act 1995 added the Australian Language and Literacy Council to the National Board of Employment, Education and Training structure—and the council had been operating as a committee of the board for several years. That is where all this was at at the time of the change of government in 1996. The government's 1996 higher education policy indicated an intention, as was always intended, to wind up the National Board of Employment, Education and Training—a measure which I would suggest was coveted by the previous government—whilst maintaining the Higher Education Council as an independent body reporting directly to the minister.
In June 1996, several months after the change of government, the Employment, Education and Training Amendment Bill 1996 was introduced to implement the election policy but it was not passed. Nonetheless, the board and the three councils wound up in response to a request from the then minister. The Higher Education Council and the Australian Research Council have continued to operate, with the board's activities being confined specifically to those councils.
The  Employment, Education and Training Amendment Bill 1999  abolishes not only the National Board of Employment, Education and Training but also the Australian Language and Literacy Council, the Employment and Skills Council, the Schools Council and the 
 Higher Education Council. The Australian Research Council will continue and will report directly to the minister. In the light of the recent release of the green paper, that is something that I suggest to the House is highly desirable. Its membership will continue unchanged. Whilst the Australian Vice-Chancellors Committee recommended that the ARC provide broad policy advice to the minister through the Higher Education Council, it nonetheless recommended that the ARC report directly to the minister on the distribution of grant funding and policies relating to its programs.
The opposition, through the member for Dobell, has made a number of points, most if not all of which need some refutation. There is no reason whatsoever on a scholarly basis to believe that the abolition of the National Board of Employment, Education and Training will reduce consultation in any way and it will certainly not reduce independent advice. What it will do is close desks in bureaucracy, possibly to open a few more in the classroom.
From what the member for Dobell has said, the opposition also has some interest in how the government will consult with other interest groups. The National Board of Employment, Education and Training, as I said, was established by the previous government, of which the member for Dobell was, I understand, a proud member. Times and funding mechanisms have changed and so too must the consultative mechanisms. The board and councils have already wound up, as I pointed out to the House, with the exception of the Australian Research Council. If expert advice is required in this area, as in so many areas of government policy direction, expert task forces can be established on an ad hoc basis. For example, we can rely upon the advice of the Business/Higher Education Round Table. I would not dare criticise its composition or its work.
I am sure that the member for Dobell would not criticise the advice that the National Council of Independent Schools Associations would give to government—or that of the Primary English Teachers Association, the National Catholic Education Commission, the 
 Australian Primary School Principals Association or the Australian Secondary School Principals Association. Are these not all sources of wise and well-informed advice to government?
We also have the centres for higher education research and development in Australia. The Australian National Training Authority also plays a pivotal role in, amongst other things, distributing vocational education and training funding to the states and institutions. The Australian Council for Education Research also does that. These and so many other organisations are, to some extent, funded by governments in one form or another and they provide a consistent and reliable source of advice without needing to maintain the National Board for Employment, Education and Training.
A number of existing representative bodies, some of which I have listed, also advise the government on issues that were once covered by the National Board of Employment, Education and Training and the four councils being abolished. Bureaucracy is very important and advice to governments of a high quality is particularly important. We need always to be asking ourselves whether maintaining any kind of board, statutory authority or, indeed, part or all of a government department actually serves the interests of not only the sector but, most importantly, the beneficiaries of it who fund it through their taxes and who ultimately should benefit from it.
Finally, the ARC will not only report directly to the minister but it will promote informed public debate on research in Australia. As the green paper on higher education research and research training actually sets out, it envisages quite a significant role in policy directions for the ARC—for which it has my full support.
Turning to some of the other points that were made by the member for Dobell, Labor, when it was in office, at times promoted higher education as the one and only definition of excellence in education. I felt that, for almost a decade, many young people were of the view that, if they did not achieve a university education and a degree, they were in some way of less value to their families and 
 society and that, even if they came out of university with two degrees, they were in some way inadequately trained. Seventy per cent of Australia's secondary students who did not go on to university could at times be forgiven for feeling that there was less of a place for them in Australian society.
The comments that the member for Dobell made about HECs and about how changes to HECs have discriminated against the interests of those seeking higher education fly in the face of reality. The reality is that, when the government changed in March 1996, only 15 per cent of students in higher education institutions in this country came from the bottom 25 per cent of income earning households. By contrast, 30 per cent came from the top 25 per cent of income earning households—with an average income then of $84,000 a year. Whatever one's definition of social justice is, I would not consider that to be my definition of it. In other words, whatever the previous government was doing to try to deliver equitable social outcomes, it was not succeeding. In other words, the taxes of blue-collar workers throughout the country were being used to fund the education principally of people who come, in many instances, from electorates like the one I am privileged to represent.
In some cases, if not many, teaching and learning in formal education took place outside the context of real life situations, activities and problems. It is essential in my view that both higher education and in particular vocational education and training take place in the context of their application. The pathways from school to university under the previous government for vocational education and training were frequently disjointed. The Dusseldorf Foundation, for example, in March last year when it published its report, Australia's youth—reality and risk, pointed out a few facts which might provide some discomfort to the Labor members of the House. It said:
We need to move from youth management to youth development.
It identified marginalised young people as being the unemployed, those who are not in the labour force or not studying and those 
 who are in precarious part-time employment. It identified the need in particular to address the problems of early school leavers. It also argued for an increased emphasis on schools to industry programs, as a consequence of which we now have the Jobs Pathway Program, which is a schools-industry partnership program, and schools, in many instances, acting as brokers. For example, $12 million was made available to them for the Jobs Pathway Program.
The Dusseldorf Foundation identified that, in 1999, this year, 15 per cent—or 187,000—15- to 19-year-olds were neither in part-time work nor in education. Of these, 70 per cent had not completed year 12. For every young person looking for work, at least one was locked into marginal activities fairly consistently for up to three years. By age 19 there had been no higher education or vocational education and training undertaken by those who had been unemployed for, in many cases, at least one-third of the time since leaving school. The report went on to say:
The key indicators for young people in leaving work during the 1990s either show no improvement or deterioration.
In fact, the key indicators for young people in learning and work during the early to mid-1990s show either no improvement or, as I say, deterioration. Youth unemployment in 1996 was no lower in real terms than it was at the beginning of the decade. Year 10 retention rates had fallen below 1990 levels. Year 11 was below the 1991 level and year 12 had fallen to the 1991 level. Those not completing year 12 were identified as being more likely to enter part-time work unlinked to study than year 12 leavers. That essentially is the picture with which the Howard government was presented in March 1996.
One of the assertions made by the member for Dobell is that enrolments in higher education are declining. Since the introduction of HECs by the Labor government in 1988, the number of enrolments in higher education in Australia has almost doubled.
