If there has been any slowing in the rate of application for higher education positions in Australia, it owes more to the substantially increased funding made available for new apprentice 
 ships and traineeships under this government and to programs which enable people to undertake vocational education and training as distinct from pursuing higher education and a degree. As I said earlier, young people were studying for degrees when, in their hearts, they were uncertain about whether they would have a job when they were finished and whether the degree was relevant to their personal interests.
Some of the other points need to be refuted. Firstly, in this budget this year—1999-2000—the government is committing over $11 billion per annum over the forward estimates for education and training. The budget saw an increased funding of $870 million for education over the next four years. This budget of over $11 billion includes approximately $5 billion for schooling, $4.2 billion for universities and $1.6 billion for vocational education and training at TAFE and through private providers. This year, direct Commonwealth funding to government schools has increased by 6.8 per cent or $115 million over the previous year.
The point that is lost in the debate, if you can describe it as debate, between the opposition and the Howard government on funding for public schools is that they are called state schools traditionally because they are funded by state governments. The Commonwealth government is not the primary funder of public schools; it is state governments. From memory, I think only 12 per cent of state school funding actually comes from the Commonwealth, but that proportion that is provided by the Commonwealth increased this year by 6.8 per cent. The government has also undertaken reforms to raise literacy and numeracy standards in the early years of school, extending it to secondary level with additional funding of $130 million over the next four years for early and middle years. Therein lies another point that ought to be made. I see that a recent survey found that those who purport to represent the interests of parents in state schools, or public schools, are actually out of step with the people they purport to represent, that over half of the parents surveyed actually disagreed with the 
 policies being espoused by those representing P&F representative organisations.
Australia's students and teachers are going to benefit from $77 million in the quality teacher program over three years to update teacher skills. And so on it goes. In terms of universities, there is another $93.3 million increase over the previous forward estimates, bringing funding to a total of $288 million over three years, and strategic partnerships with industry research and training grants will be allocated another almost $60 million funding to forge stronger links between industry and universities, bringing it to $162 million over three years.
One of the other points that I think ought to be made which is perhaps more of a philosophical nature is that in undertaking these reforms, in abolishing the National Board of Employment, Education and Training and undertaking the other reforms which are included in this bill, we need to reflect upon what is actually the purpose of education. One of the debates that we have not really had is whether education increasingly should be seen to take on a purely utilitarian view or whether on the other hand education should be about learning for life, about education itself. One of the concerns I have is that, increasingly, young people are pursuing training as distinct from education. I say that as a person who was trained as distinct from educated. One of the most compelling speeches that I have read on this was given, not surprisingly perhaps, by Professor David Penington to the Melbourne Winter Conversazione for 1995. I will just quote a couple of things from that address. He said:
The rapid changes that are occurring in the world of work mean that vocational education must increasingly be accompanied by general education. Otherwise, graduates will be trained in skills which will fast disappear and they will be left with little capacity for adaptation and change.
He went on to say:
Control of education to an undue degree by central government in terms of detailed prescriptions of a uniform kind, whether these be national curriculum frameworks or uniform indicators of performance for all institutions of higher education, carries profound dangers. Unless the diversity of human potential is recognised and adequately catered for, 
 not only will individual young people be the losers but the future development of society itself will also suffer.
It is time for countries such as our own to rethink their approaches to education in order to achieve what he described as the proud Confucian tradition of Asian nations in respect for teachers and for education. If we do not, he warned, we could be left far behind. I speak strongly in support of this bill. It is a move in the right direction. It reduces complexity of administration and increases consultation.

name: Ferguson, Martin, MP
text:
—In talking this afternoon to the Employment, Education and Training Amendment Bill 1999 , it is my view that the bill is about accountability, independent advice and a judgment made on the importance of public debate. I say that because of the close link between those who do poorly in education, those who do poorly in the labour market and the one in nine Australians who live in poverty. These very facts make it clear that governments do not have all the solutions. This is precisely why they need independent advice.
It is for that reason that the shadow minister for education, the member for Dobell, moved a second reading amendment this afternoon. It raises some fundamental issues. I specifically refer, firstly, to acknowledgment by this side of the House that in our opinion education and training are of fundamental importance to Australia's social and economic wellbeing. That is why we have a view, as we move forward to a new century, that the debate ought to be about Australia being a knowledge based society, one that fundamentally acknowledges and supports and invests in our future as a leading nation which regards education and training as being of paramount importance. We then go on to make this important commitment—if anything a reaffirmation of what the Australian Labor Party committed itself to in the lead-up to the last election. This commitment is set out in point (5) of the second reading amendment moved by the shadow minister. It states that when returned to government we will re-establish a structure to provide independent 
 cross-sectoral advice on education and training.
It is for that very reason that today I want to discuss the sort of work that some of these groups have undertaken in the past and why it is so important for the Australian community that there ought to be a source of independent advice on such a fundamental issue as education and training. I want to also suggest that the government may have a particular interest in doing these organisations over. When you look across the range of portfolios that exist under the current government, you see this is not the only source of independent advice that previously existed that the government has gone out of its way to undermine, to white-ant and to remove. I believe politicians ought to acknowledge that they do not have all the solutions, that there is a case for independent advice, and that, if anything, the best policy actually comes from debate and a willingness by independent public servants and a network of organisations that offer that independent advice to actually challenge you on the policy front. That is what I believe the organisations that are being abolished by this bill actually sought to do in days gone by.
Mr Deputy Speaker, as you, I and the Australian community know, Australia's No. 1 economic and social problem is unemployment. That is intimately linked to the debate this afternoon. The budget and the $20 million squandered on buying the GST make it clear that it is not the government's priority, but that does not change the reality. The fact is that unemployment is the biggest economic and social problem we face and, despite what the Treasurer and the Prime Minister would have had us believe in question time today, we have not made enough progress. Yes, unemployment today stands at 7.2 per cent, but the Prime Minister failed to mention to the House today that, since the current government was elected in March 1996, the participation rate in Australia has actually fallen by almost one per cent. That has been a major factor in reducing the unemployment rate in Australia.
The Prime Minister also failed to acknowledge, when he talked about the strength of 
 the Australian economy today, that he in actual fact inherited a very strong economy. I read with interest a speech by the Prime Minister at a function in Newcastle, just a couple of Fridays ago, about some very famous Newcastle identities, one of whom was a fellow by the name of Maurie Rudd, a leading trade union official in Newcastle and a major representative of iron workers involved in the steel industry and related industries. On reading that speech, I found an acknowledgment by the Prime Minister that 18 months ago he was not sure or confident that the Australian economy would weather the Asian storm but that he was pleased that we had weathered the Asian storm.
The reason we have weathered the Asian storm, despite some mismanagement by this government and the fact that it slashed and burned in its first couple of budgets and made it far more difficult for us to perform, is that this government actually did inherit a very strong economy. The fundamental changes were made in the 13 years prior to 1996. The major changes that went to make a modern-looking economy, which included significant investment in education and training, were what the Prime Minister inherited.
For that very reason, when we talk about the issue of unemployment, we should also face up to the facts. Yes, we have 7.2 per cent unemployment at the moment and, yes, the participation rate has actually fallen by almost one per cent since March 1996, but more importantly—and this is of fundamental importance—on the basis of the economy that the Prime Minister inherited we should be talking about an unemployment rate of five per cent or a little bit more at this time.
It is interesting to acknowledge that was not only the view of this side of the House after the 1996 election but also the independent view of the Department of Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs which at that time—despite an endeavour by the minister to suggest that five per cent could not be achieved—acknowledged very publicly that we were on target to achieve an unemployment rate of five per cent. So when we talk about the issue of education and training it is important that we associate with it the 
 question of how we perform as a nation, whether or not the economy is functioning well and whether or not we are actually making enough progress on the employment front.
To us on this side of the House, that is important when we are talking about these issues, because we believe that the issue of education and training or lack thereof is the single biggest cause of poverty and material hardship. But, even more than this, it is important because it can give to or deny people, our fellow citizens, a crucial means of self-worth and personal dignity. That is what one's fundamental achievement on the education and training front is about, because one's achievement on that front also determines to a large extent one's opportunity in life. It determines the nature of the job that one might be able to achieve and also one's capacity, in a rapidly changing economy, to maintain a reasonable level of employability.
That is what the new debate is about. It is not about the sense of security that previously existed in many jobs because of the nature of employment that existed in a range of different industries in days gone by. The new debate is about knowledge. It is about investment in education and training, which is fundamentally linked to one's employability over one's working life. That is why, in this context, we must always be willing to ensure that we are challenged by independent advice—from organisations such as those that will be abolished by this bill—to make sure that we get it right on the education and training front. We must do that so we get it right when it comes to ensuring that we do our best to ensure that throughout people's working lives they have a capacity to maintain decent employment opportunities because we have invested in a fundamental way in their employability.
Mr Deputy Speaker, you—and especially those on the other side of the House—might wonder why we so significantly relate this issue to the question of unemployment. The unemployment problem is not a simple one. It goes to a number of issues. One of the most consistent relationships that you will find over time is that between educational 
 outcomes and the chances of unemployment. The Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business has said that he is not interested in new and creative solutions to unemployment. I am pleased to say that the Labor Party is, always has been and always will be interested in creative solutions to reduce unemployment in Australia.
That is why we want a debate about ideas. We do not want, as the Minister for Employment Services would have it, name calling and pointing the finger at the unemployed and those in depressed suburbs or regions who actually find it very difficult to get a job at this point in time. It should be a debate about ideas, not about name calling and pointing the figure. That is why, when we listen to what the community has to say, we understand that the analysis, the questions and the debate come before the answers. That is where some of the research by NBEET and the Schools Council in particular fits in. Their work, I believe, is an important part of the broader literature on the link between educational and labour market disadvantage. That is what it is about when you talk about employability. That is what it is about when you talk about someone's self-worth and someone's capacity to get a decent life through a capacity to get a job. It is about overcoming educational and labour market disadvantage.
What this research shows is that those who struggle in the labour market are those who have struggled in the education system. And it even goes beyond this. We must ask why people struggle in education. Not surprisingly, one finds that outcomes in education are largely driven by individual environments. Parents, peers and other personal and social support networks all affect educational outcomes in a fundamental way. Ultimately, it is these educational outcomes that largely determine labour market prospects.
NBEET and the Schools Council have played their part in this debate. The Labor Party in government did not always like the advice of these organisations, but we were prepared to at least be challenged and to consider their independent advice. That is what the strength of government and leadership is about: acknowledging that you are 
 open to debate and new ideas. It is therefore disillusioning that people charged with public responsibilities—as are this Prime Minister and minister for education—want to shy away from such a debate. Why is the government so scared of this debate? Why is it so keen to silence these organisations? Clearly, it is because the government does not think it needs independent advice. It thinks that a narrow ideology will deliver the real world explanations and solutions. Is it because these organisations are committed to decent principles of social justice, and the coalition has as much faith in the word `social' as it does in the words `union' and `collective'? Of course it is hard to believe in social justice if you think there is no such thing as society or a sense of community.
This Howard government wants to silence these organisations because when these organisations look at the facts and analyse the evidence they come to conclusions that shake the coalition government right to its philosophical roots. They spell it out: society is more than the sum of its individuals. The truth is that our environments matter; our educational opportunities matter; where we live matters; what types of jobs our parents have matter; and what industries exist in our regions or our suburbs matter. You need the facts and the independent advice to actually work out the solutions to overcome those barriers that are getting worse in the Australian community. The gap between those who have and those who do not have is actually widening because of the inability of this government to admit that there is a need for further action and for new solutions.
The fact that we depend on others and that others depend on us is more than the starting assumption needed for us to develop practical solutions. It is the very basis of a just society. What the government must understand is that incorporating a social dimension makes the policy development task much more difficult, and it is easier to ignore it. To actually incorporate the social dimension is a challenge to those in government.
When experts analyse a problem and find that the explanations for poor educational and labour market outcomes are complex, you 
 must begin to acknowledge that simple solutions are not enough. Broader acceptance of the fact that solutions to unemployment must take into account the influence of schools, families and communities—the support systems that surround us every day of our lives—would be a critical step forward in the government's approach. It is unfortunate that this government is not prepared to acknowledge the importance of support systems, for when narrow individualism is all you have you continue to tear at the nation's social fabric. This is evident to all but those who are not prepared to look.
The fact that today we have 680,000 people unemployed—and that is an understatement of the problem—suggests that governments have failed to appreciate this. That is why Labor is committed to a comprehensive approach to improving educational outcomes and reducing unemployment. Complex problems require solutions that are well thought out and subject to independent scrutiny. On this side of the House, we welcome that scrutiny. In developing solutions we must recognise the links between economic outcomes and the social context. We must recognise how the education system affects the labour market, and we must have the research that tells us what is going on, not just our own view but independent research at arms-length to government. We need research that is factually based and capable of challenging the government about new solutions. We must all recognise the vital role that education plays in shaping our individual and collective futures. Labor is clearly prepared to listen to independent advice on these issues; the coalition government is not.
As shadow minister for employment and training, I am interested in whatever the facts, analysis and independent advice throw up. Labor is interested in and committed to developing real and workable solutions. Compare that approach with the coalition's approach to this bill. The bill, in truth, puts the nail into the coffin of these institutions that were exceptionally important in providing independent advice to government. The truth is that the government buried them long ago by gutting them of resources. In a democratic 
 society neither the facts nor different opinions, especially when they are informed opinions, are dangerous. We should cherish such an approach to government.
If we choose to, we can listen to each other, learn from each other and seek to understand each other. It is unfortunate when a government fundamentally misunderstands what education, knowledge and the pursuit of understanding can do for us. When governments discard independent advice they discard the accountability that is central to our political system. It is the sort of action that too often lets this government masquerade social injustice as mere misfortune. It is the sort of theme unfortunately pursued all too often by representatives of this government's front bench as they walk away from real debate and from an endeavour to engage the Australian community in a debate about finding real solutions.
I simply suggest in conclusion that Australia deserves better than this bill. Australia wants to and should be a knowledge based society—a society that is prepared to be challenged and a society that expects that in government we support independent advice and challenges to our ideas. This bill continues the government's process of ripping out any sense of independence of the Australian Public Service. The government is gutting it. They put political clowns in key positions as secretaries to departments and then dismiss them willy-nilly if they do not like their advice. When it comes to engaging others in the broader community—parents or unions or community organisations or representatives of educational institutions—the government says, `No, we are not interested in your advice; we know better. After all, we've got a minister for education, Dr Kemp, who can write a book.' He has written a book, but he is not prepared to think about independent advice and to be challenged.
I challenge the government to revisit today's bill—to reaffirm independence of government and the need for independent advice and analysis. The Labor Party again gives that commitment. On re-election, we will re-establish a structure to provide independent cross-sectoral advice on education 
 and training. The Australian community deserves that.

name: Kelly, De-Anne, MP
text:
—I rise to speak on the Employment, Education and Training Amendment Bill 1999 . I could not agree more with the shadow minister that education and training are very important. Unfortunately, though, Labor's results with regard to unemployment give a lie to this assertion. I simply cannot believe that the shadow minister opposite is criticising the 7.2 per cent level of unemployment that the coalition has been able to achieve. The Labor Party in government were responsible for the highest postwar level of unemployment of 11.2 per cent. The member for Batman said we should be looking at five per cent. Along with `the cheque is in the mail', another one of those great myths of the 20th century is, `The Labor Party was on target for its 14th year to achieve that.' Fortunately, the Australian people had a say in that and Labor are now enjoying the opposition benches.
I will now speak about the bill specifically. In its 1996 policy statement on higher education, the coalition undertook to abolish the National Board of Employment, Education and Training and to establish independent councils to advise the government on higher education and research. This bill marks the beginning of that process. That policy entitled `Quality, Diversity and Choice' recognised that the existing administrative structure of advisory boards introduced by the Hawke Labor government in 1988 was cumbersome, unwieldy and not attuned to the policy directions of the coalition. Under the Labor Party structure, which this bill seeks to abolish and replace, the Australian Language and Literacy Council, the Australian Research Council, the Employment and Skills Council, the Higher Education Council and the Schools Council all reported to the minister via the national board.
While superficially this may have seemed a good idea inasmuch as it provided the minister with some sort of grandiose plan and big picture strategy, it was a recipe for dissension and pettiness, as the various interests and causes felt that their arguments, recommendations and perspectives were being filtered by 
 the overarching national board. There was, as there is now, a feeling that the national board exercised too much power and influence in recommending preferred priorities to the minister and the government. As the Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs made clear when introducing this bill, the coalition has a policy of ensuring that policy advice from all of the key areas flows directly to the minister. The need for a board which filters this advice is obviously redundant.
I believe that the education, training and research community will welcome this bill, as it allows them via the new structure to present their views directly to the minister and the government. This represents a very significant breakthrough in providing a higher and far more relevant standard of advice for the minister and the government. Thus this bill will abolish the national board, the Australian Language and Literacy Council, the Employment and Skills Council, the Schools Council and the Higher Education Council. The Australian Research Council will continue to be an independent council reporting directly to the minister. It is the government's intention to create more independent councils which will report directly to the minister, and this bill flags that future creation. The Australian Research Council will continue with its membership unchanged and will report annually to the minister on its operations. That report will be tabled.
The minister and the government are to be congratulated for this move, which not only introduces a new level of accountability and transparency but cuts the stifling and divisive red-tape procedures of the national board established by Labor. Members of the new councils will be able to more clearly focus on their relevant responsibilities and not be distracted by unwanted intrusions, censorship and potential direct meddling by the national board.
While the coalition's policy document was entitled `Quality, Diversity and Choice', it also included the notion of flexibility in obtaining that advice. We can only wonder why Labor did not want specialist advisory bodies to report directly to the minister when 
 a critical aspect of formulating policy is an uncensored and vigorous public debate.
Under the coalition's policy, to encourage this healthy open philosophy there will be the flexibility to establish expert ad hoc task forces to advise on specific issues as they arise, and of course there are the many existing representative bodies which can and will give the government advice on issues previously covered by the national board and the four councils which are to be abolished.
It is appropriate, within the general policy context that this bill partially addresses, to consider the greater matter of diversity and choice in education. Australian parents are increasingly adopting a marketplace ideology and are shopping around before choosing their children's schools. They are making decisions about choice not only between school sectors—government or non-government—but also within sectors as states abandon government school zoning.
Of non-government schools, religious affiliation is most often the overriding consideration for school choice. Other considerations are whether the school is co-educational or single sex and the travelling distance from the family home. Smaller school sizes are also an attraction, with growing evidence that many problems of students in schools are less acute in smaller schools. Other criteria include a school's academic performance and discipline policy.
The coalition government has been a staunch supporter of the right of Australian parents to choose the most appropriate schooling for their child. Educational choice is seen by the government as the capacity of parents to choose between schools in the government sector or to select and/or establish a non-government school. The government's abolition of the new schools policy—or, as it is more commonly known, the no schools policy—which placed restrictions on the establishment of new non-government schools, was the first demonstration of the coalition government's commitment to supporting freedom of educational choice. The new model of funding non-government schools is another step, with one of its stated 
 goals to give low income families greater access to the school of their choice.
In the ministerial statement launching the new funding model for non-government schools, Dr Kemp stated:
Parental choice has prompted quality in schooling, and ensures that Australian children receive an education which reflects the values of their community. Non-government schools are a living reflection of the breadth of our community.
As early as 1973, the Interim Committee for the Australian Schools Commission, in its landmark report, Schools in Australia —known as the Karmel Report—acknowledged the value of diversity and high standards that it saw present in non-government schools. It also supported the right of parents to educate their children outside the government school sector. Since the publication of this report, research and official government statistics have continually reinforced the perception that students from non-government schools have better educational outcomes than students from government schools. According to a report released in March this year in the Australian School Monitor , non-Catholic private schools increase a student's chance of graduating from secondary school by 21 per cent and from university by seven per cent. The raw data from that study shows that 36 per cent of government school students graduate from year 12 compared with 68 per cent of non-Catholic private school students, and 31 per cent of the latter complete university compared with 12 per cent of government school students.	 Results from the 1996 National Schools English Literacy Survey, reported by the Sydney Catholic Archdiocese, point to similar outcomes for primary school students, with Catholic school students performing above the national average.
It would be remiss of me not to say at this opportune time that the Catholic Education Office in Rockhampton, which also services my area of Mackay, have asked me to pass on their heartfelt thanks for the support the federal government has given to their schools. They wanted me to personally thank the Prime Minister for the outstanding support that the coalition has given to Catholic schools in my area. Many of those Catholic schools are in needy areas and parents are not 
 able to give the support that parents in other areas are able to give. The increased federal funding has been of significant assistance to those schools.
Some argue that the new diversity in educational choice, with 146 new non-government schools approved for Commonwealth funding in 1997 and 1998, is a threat to Australia's social cohesion and egalitarian tradition. Counters to these concerns include the acceptance and consideration of the multicultural composition of Australian society and a reflection of a system responsive to the concerns and demands of parents.
It certainly seems that outcomes achieved by state schools across Australia are behind those achieved by the private and Catholic school sectors. Nobody is suggesting that this is because the brightest and best students have abandoned the state school system; nor, as I have said, is it a matter of socioeconomic disadvantage, since many of the Catholic Church schools choose the most needy areas in which to set up their schools.
Retention rates for students in the non-state sector are consistently higher. In 1998, across the nation government schools achieved a 65.7 per cent retention rate to year 12 while the non-state sector had a rate of 84.8 per cent. The fall-off in retention rates occurs in years 11 and 12, the two critical years that really determine a student's career path and direction if higher education is to be an option. At the end of year 10 the retention rates for both systems were above 95 per cent, but the slump in the rates for the state system after that grade was appalling.
On the general subject of retention rates, there has been a steady decline since 1992 when an impressive 77.1 per cent of all students stayed to year 12. In the three following years—1993, 1994 and 1995—there was a very worrying fall to 72.2 per cent. This decline happened at a time when the percentage of school-age children at government schools declined.
Clearly, parents are opting for the non-government sector if and when they can afford it. It is no secret that Labor Party members, who champion the cause of the state system both in and out of parliament, do 
 not wait a second to enrol their children in non-government schools when their income permits it. I recall that recently the Premier of Queensland, the Hon. Peter Beattie, was asked where his children attended school. Significantly, he declined to answer the question. However, I am charitable and see this as a manifestation of a strongly emerging trend by parents across the spectrum to send their children to schools that provide the best opportunities. I would like to say at this juncture, in defence of state schools, that they take all comers. Every student is accepted and that needs to be taken into account when looking at the results and outcomes they achieve. This does not mean that there are not state schools and teachers who work with professionalism and enthusiasm to equip their students for life. There are certainly many outstanding examples of this, but nationally the results are disappointing.
In 1996, there were 9,630 geographically isolated schools in Australia, both primary and secondary, which were eligible for funding under the Commonwealth's Country Areas Program, known as CAP. States face greater difficulties in staffing isolated schools than in staffing schools in capital cities or other urban areas. Student participation in education in isolated areas often requires additional time, effort and commitment on the part of students and their families than would generally be the case in an urban community.
Generally across Australia, secondary school completion rates have been lower in rural areas than in metropolitan areas. In the 1980s there was roughly a 10 per cent difference in year 12 completion rates between urban and rural students. By 1994 the difference in completion rates between urban and rural female students remained the same, but the recent national decline in school completion rates has been far greater for boys in rural areas than for those living in the city.
Rural students are also underrepresented in higher education. In 1996, their share of student enrolments was around 18 per cent. Rural students' share of commencing enrolments has declined steadily since 1991 when it was 19.6 per cent. Students from isolated areas comprised only 2.1 per cent of com 
 mencing students in 1996. The limitations of post-school options for geographically isolated students has been reported by a number of states, with decreasing local options for employment and limited options for post-secondary education without moving to a capital city or other large urban centre being the major concerns. The lack of post-school options is also seen as contributing to the decreasing number of senior secondary students.
These concerns were reinforced by the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission report, Bush Talks, released earlier this year. It reported that rural drop-out rates were double those in the city and that the percentage of rural young people taking up tertiary studies was continuing to decline. For those of us who believe in rural and regional Australia, this is very disappointing news, as is the lack of opportunities for young people in areas outside the metropolitan cities. Government needs to address this most serious matter and ensure that students from rural areas are given every possible encouragement to continue their education. As our minister, though, has started, I have no doubt that he will finish. The bill that is before the House is one that I commend and support.

name: Gillard, Julia, MP
text:
—As the recent budget made clear, this government's vision for education is limited to cutbacks and to punishment. A quick look at the last budget confirms that this is the case. Government school kids were punished and given a paltry $10 extra per year while their private school counterparts received $210 extra per year—$10 for 70 per cent of school kids and a favoured 30 per cent get $210. Universities received less for teaching, and the government's own university equity scholarships were scrapped. TAFE, the sector on which we fundamentally depend for the provision of lifelong learning opportunities, received no growth funding at all. The key to our future competitiveness—research and innovation—was dealt a blow, and its share of GDP will fall from 0.78 per cent in 1995-96 to 0.63 per cent in 1999-2000.
But you do not have to actually take the word of the opposition—the word of our side 
 of politics—to expose this government's and this minister's lack of vision on the question of education policy. Indeed, as referred to in question time today, one of his principal critics is the Liberal Minister for Education in Victoria, Mr Phil Gude, who has said about the performance of the federal Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs, amongst other things:
Literacy is our highest priority and, despite Dr Kemp undermining the previous collaborative process, we are determined this important process goes ahead.
And:
He ought to do the right thing . . . own up to the fact that he's manipulated the figures in a most dishonest and disgraceful fashion.
He has also said:
It is a debate that has hit the public arena as a result of political grandstanding by Dr Kemp.
Education policy under this government is not about vision. But despite its lack of vision for education, this government does have an agenda for education: to give the minister an unfettered ability to punish and to blame anyone and everyone except himself and this government for the problems in the education system.
This minister knows that he does not have any answers, but he wants to make absolutely sure that he and he alone gets to pick the scapegoat for the problem. Today it might be the teachers unions, tomorrow it might be the student unions or, even more fashionably according to yesterday's newspapers, it might be the so-called poorly performing schools. The minister wants to be able to do that free of the scrutiny of independent and expert advisory bodies. He wants to be able to do that without being subject to criticism from those with the credentials to proffer intelligent and perceptive criticisms. When you do not have a vision for education, what you absolutely do not want is independent expert advisory bodies blowing the whistle on you and letting people know that you do not have that vision.
Indeed, at base, that is the purpose of the Employment Education and Training Amendment Bill 1999. This legislation is about ensuring that those bodies, which could 
 expose by their advice and their reports the huge holes in this government's approach to education, do not exist anymore. Stripped to its essence, this legislation is about burying the able representative bodies this government has, in effect, already killed. This legislation is really about burying the corpses of those bodies which have already been killed by executive action—by stopping funds and appointments.
There is no other justification for this legislation. One can read the minister's second reading speech time and time again—it does not take very long to read; it is a nice short one—and not find any real justification for this legislation. That is because the justification that really underpins this legislation is something that he would not want to put on as public a record as Hansard. The real purpose of this legislation is to silence critics and to silence possible sources of alternate advice.
So how does the legislation go about that process? This bill abolishes the National Board of Employment, Education and Training—commonly known as NBEET—and its councils. It does maintain—and at least this is one point of merit in the bill—the Australian Research Council. But, in abolishing NBEET and its councils, this bill overturns a 40-year tradition of having in this country independent and authoritative bodies in the education area from which to draw advice; that is—if I might put it like this—a conservative tradition, one started off by a conservative government and which ranged over 40 years. This bill basically gets rid of 40 years of independent and authoritative advice.
What could be a justification for that? I guess a justification for that could be that the government had looked at NBEET and its councils and said to itself, `They're not doing their job.' That could be a justification for this legislation. But when you turn to the facts and actually look at them, does that justification ring true? Does it hold up? I do not think so. I do not think the facts support any claim that NBEET or its councils were not doing their job. In dealing with this point, I turn to the 1994 Wiltshire review of NBEET which found: 
The actual record of NBEET, in terms of measurable output, has been impressive by any yardstick.
The review goes on to state:
There would be few comparable research organisations in the country which could match the NBEET productivity/equality record.
The Wiltshire review also provided us with numerous examples of NBEET's work which has been recognised externally as having a significant impact on the education debate in this country and on education policy. I turn briefly to some of those quality publications and reports which have been generated by NBEET and its councils. From the Higher Education Council, which up until this bill reported annually on the impact of the higher education scheme, we had the document Achieving quality (in higher education).  From the Schools Council, which was charged with the responsibility of advising on primary and secondary education, we had the document Australia's teachers—an agenda for the next decade.  From the Employment and Skills Formation Council, which advises on matters relating to TAFE and employment, we had the document The Australian vocational certificate training system.  From NBEET itself we had the document Fitting the need  which highlighted the need to address the `big picture' resource issues across all education sectors.
So the government is completely unable to maintain the claim that NBEET's demise has anything to do with a failure on its part. On the contrary, the government is fully aware of this fact and has instead adopted a strategy of death by starvation and has simply refused to appoint new members to NBEET and its councils. What is almost wearying about this process is that we have been down this path before. The government tried to go down this path in 1996. It tried then to abolish NBEET and it presented a bill to this House in order to do so.
It should be noted that the bill we are dealing with today contains a worse proposition than the 1996 legislation. In the 1996 proposal the government was going to keep the Higher Education Council. That was used among the education constituency and community, which ought to include all of us, as 
 a central selling point for the government's claim that accountability and independence would not be eroded. In the bill before us, the Higher Education Council, which was the primary source of advice under NBEET on general higher education issues, is also to be tossed aside. It is to be thrown on the scrap heap along with the other councils deemed to be no longer relevant to the government's agenda and from which the government does not want to see scrutiny, proposals and expert independent advice.
In 1996, the bill that was introduced in this House was the subject of a Senate inquiry. Specifically, the Senate Employment, Education and Training Legislation Committee inquired into the Employment, Education and Training Amendment Bill 1996 as it was then proposed. It is worthwhile recapping some of the principal findings of that Senate inquiry because the committee's very perceptive comments apply to the bill before the House today. The Senate committee found that the `overall thrust of the evidence received by the committee'—that is, the Senate committee—`argued for the importance of portfolio advisory mechanisms being independent and publicly accountable.' Further, the committee found that `the requirement for independence ensured that government departments and agencies did not monopolise the advice available to the minister.' That is, the minister would have the benefit, when making very important decisions, of very diverse advice from diverse communities; the minister would not be captive to the bureaucracy or to narrow sections of advisory structures. Instead, the minister would have available a full range of advice.
Indeed, taking that imperative to get the fullest and most comprehensive advice, the Senate committee recommended that the reports arising from whatever advisory structure eventuated be tabled in the parliament within 15 days of their receipt by the minister, so that advice could be available to parliament generally. So concerned was the Senate committee about the implications of the government agenda as it then was in 1996 that the committee went further and suggested that any future alternate advisory framework 
 be expedited to fill the void left by the abolition of NBEET. It was basically saying, `If you are going to do away with this advisory structure, make sure that you put something else in its place as soon as possible. Don't leave yourself, as a minister, as a government, without the wider sources of advice, without independent sources of advice, without authoritative sources of advice.' In 1996, the government did not in any way outline what, if any, alternate structure was proposed had that bill gone through. In today's circumstances, where we are dealing with this bill as it is presented to this House, that same criticism remains as strong today as it was in 1996—and that is, what next, what else, where to from here, where are we going to go? All those questions remain unanswered.
The submissions before the Senate committee also focused on the important cross-sectoral role played by NBEET. Independent of government, independent of lobbyists, NBEET could consider the implication of advice to the minister across all sectors. It could synthesise and balance out competing claims from the various constituencies and sectors in education. As we are all aware, the education system in this country—dealing as it does with the education of our very youngest children right through to the adult education sector, our university sector and our drive to create lifelong learning opportunities—is such a complex sector, with its many parts, that it is obviously going to provide advice to a minister from its various bits. There needs to be a balancing out, an overall view. If you are going to get an authoritative view, you really need to be considering what each sector is saying, how the sectors relate to each other and what is best for the sector overall. That is, of course, a principal role that NBEET has played in advising government. Yet, despite the Senate committee's focus on that as an issue, the government has studiously ignored the impact of the single coordinated framework for advice on employment, education, training and research policies and programs.
The Senate inquiry also highlighted concerns over the shift to a greater reliance on departmental advice, not only because the department has a very specific role in terms 
 of delivering government policy but also because it has difficulty—again, I quote the Senate committee—`gaining cooperation from the full range of agencies from which the department itself sought information in order to monitor implementation of policies and initiatives'. So there was an issue about gaining the best possible cooperation across the sector.
Examples of the need to keep yourself as close as possible to the sector and of the role that an advisory structure like NBEET and its councils can play—the role that is already lacking because, in effect, NBEET and its councils have been killed by slow starvation—have already been provided by Leigh Tobrett, the Director of the Office of Higher Education in the Queensland Department of Education. It concerns the issue of the government's approach to the overenrolment of universities last year.
The government—abstracted as it is from the day-to-day process of the higher education sector here in Canberra, not out there at a university actually dealing with the day-to-day process—claimed when the overenrolment issue came to light that `universities were poor at managing their enrolment processes, had strategically overenrolled to get their hands on the subsidy for overenrolment offered for the first time by the government, and that it was a sign that the sector was overfunded'. This is what we were told by someone who was on the ground or in better touch with the on-the-ground issues than this government:
A quick reality check with the sector would have developed another view on that issue, and save the Minister an irritated and hostile response from the sector which in the long run is bad for both parties. That over-enrolment was an outcome of a genuine concern about the punitive action if targets were not met, at a time when the impact of second semester enrolments was still being tested, and planned resource cuts of around 17 per cent loomed large on the horizon.
That is a small example—not an unimportant example—of the type of problem happening out there on the ground in the education sector—the distance between what is happening out there and what government can build. It is that kind of distance that NBEET and its 
 councils—independent as they were, cross-sectoral as they were, expert as they were—helped to bridge. By starving NBEET and its councils to death, the government has put itself in the position—it certainly will be post the passage of this bill—where there is no effective structure to bridge that gap.
Anybody who looks at it closely would have to conclude that that is very bad public policy which is not going to drive our education sector forward in the way that we as a community would like to see it go forward, given how convinced I think Australians are of the fundamental and pivotal role played by education in our society and increasingly played as we work within a more globalised economic setting.
To summarise what is wrong with this bill and why it is bad public policy, let us again count through the points. It is bad public policy because, firstly, we need quality literature in the area of education and a source of that will be lost without NBEET and its councils. We need quality, authoritative reports. We will not have them. Secondly, we need independent bodies—independent of government and the bureaucracy—to be analysing the sector and providing advice upon it. Thirdly, we need cross-sectoral bodies, bodies that are across the complexity and breadth of the education sector, can look at all of its parts and also, very importantly, can look at the whole. Fourthly, we need expert bodies which are close to the ground, in touch with the education community, the education constituency, reporting on the problems, needs and issues as they see them day-to-day as they go about their work.
Each of those reasons, I would have thought, would have convinced a government that this bill represents flawed public policy. Unfortunately, we have not convinced the minister of that. As I said at the outset, I think that is because the minister is in the business of centralising to himself all power in relation to the education sector. I suspect the motive for doing that is that he does not want the actions of himself as minister and this government in the education sector to be subject to scrutiny, to balance, to independent oversight and to independent bodies having a 
 look at what he is doing. He wants to be in the blame game. He wants to pick the victims. He wants to tell us what is going wrong and we know for sure that it is never going to be him; it is always going to be someone else. The day after the budget, in its editorial the Australian stated:
The poor provision for higher and further education in Tuesday's federal Budget laid bare an incomplete thought process.
We can only speculate how bare and incomplete a thought process we are now going to get, given the contents of this bill.

name: Hall, Jill, MP
text:
—The Employment, Education and Training Amendment Bill 1999  seeks to amend the Employment, Education and Training Act 1988, to abolish the National Board of Employment, Education and Training—NBEET—and its subsidiary councils: the Australian Language and Literacy Council, the Employment and Skills Council, the Schools Council and the Higher Education Council. All these councils and NBEET have had a long history of providing quality reports and quality scrutiny and advice to governments. This bill also seeks to amend the act to retain the Australian Research Council, which will report directly to the Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs. At least we can be grateful for the fact that one of these councils is going to survive the minister's assault.
This is the Howard government's second attempt to abolish NBEET. The 1996 legislation did not progress through the parliament. The difference between this and the 1996 legislation is that the Higher Education Council is also a casualty of the minister's knife, slicing into the councils that have operated independently in our country, looking at the education, training, skill and employment needs of Australians. We might ask why the minister has gone down the path of deciding to abolish the Higher Education Council when previously he had decided that maybe it did have a role to play and that he would leave it in place. I would like to argue that the reason he is abolishing that council is that he does not like what it is saying. It is the same old story: if you do not like the message, shoot the messenger.
The 1992 report looked at the impact of the government's HECS policies in 1991 and it showed that there was no impact on socially disadvantaged students. Unfortunately, the 1997 report was not quite as convincing in what it had to say. It indicated that government policies were impacting on socially disadvantaged students. There had been a drop in enrolments and, generally speaking, all the indicators that were in place showed that this government's policy was attacking those people who needed the most support to be able to attend university and gain an education, to be put on the same footing as other students who came from a more socially advantaged background. The 1998 report, which was looking at this issue in a little bit more depth, has been lost. Where it is no-one knows. Hopefully it will turn up, but I suspect it will not turn up whilst this government is in power.
The Howard government has really had a vendetta against universities and those students who are not socially advantaged. They have cut the operational grants to universities and they have reduced the HECS repayment threshold. Even the changes that they have made in the area of youth allowance have impacted on students attending university. I have a son and daughter who both go to university, and I have only to listen to them and their friends talking. They worry about the huge debt they are incurring. They know that the policies that this government has put in place are affecting their ability to obtain education. A number of their friends whose parents are unable to support them have had to leave university and get jobs. Some of them are able to attend on a part-time basis, but overall this government's policies are biting and affect the most disadvantaged students.
I think their policies are having the effect that the government want; they are making sure that it is only those people who have money, who are wealthy, the so-called elite—their friends—are the ones who can access university education. Even before the last election, when I was out doorknocking I came across a young woman who complained bitterly to me about the way she was having 
 to pay back many thousands of dollars because of the changes this government had made to the HECS repayment threshold.
University education should be there for everyone. It should not be there only for the wealthy and the elite. It should be something that ordinary Australians and ordinary Australians students who attend public school can access. I really do not believe that is the case with this government. The Howard government's 1999 education budget directed dollars to students attending private schools. They received 21 times more money than public schools. This means that those private schools, particularly those elite private schools, are going to have greater resources. They are going to advantage those students attending those schools: they will have more computers; those students interested in sport will have greater access to elite sporting programs; and all the time the gap between those who are socially advantaged and those who are socially disadvantaged will get bigger and bigger.
This is this government's idea of cross-subsidisation: subsidise the wealthy private schools at the expense of the public schools. I have grown up with the concept that you help those people who need assistance, those in greatest need. But this government says, `If you have got money, if you are advantaged, we will give you a bit more.' Students who are attending public schools are disadvantaged by this government's policies. Then they are disadvantaged by the impact of this government's policies when they attend university. Once again, it is making education affordable and accessible only for the wealthy. Abolition of the merit based equity scholarships has been a further step down the path of supporting those who have at the expense of those who have not or those that are more socially disadvantaged.
The minister is closed to any new ideas or anything that is different from his own ideas. He has pushed through his ideas relating to student unions and pushed for voluntary student unionism. Even his programs that look at literacy and numeracy are about testing rather than about actually improving the literacy and numeracy skills of students. The 
 minister and, I am afraid, the Prime Minister are both idealogues. They are trapped in the 1950s and they cannot get out. This government is an antieducation government, a government that supports only organisations, groups, boards or councils that support its points of view, its doctrines, its ideology.
That is why NBEET was doomed. NBEET was a body that offered independent advice and had independent, new ideas—something this government objects to. You must fit inside the box, you must be philosophically correct, you must lack innovation, you must be controllable. If you are not, you are out, you are cut, you are abolished—it is the end of you. And that is the problem with NBEET and its councils. The councils had community representatives. We all know what this government thinks about community representatives. Its attitude is: `We don't want the community to be involved. We don't want the community to have a say. We don't want any of those ideas to sneak into a report to the government.' Otherwise, it may actually have to look at them or consider them. It wants people it can control. Therefore, what do you do? You abolished the board and its councils.
NBEET has been effectively abolished for some time, because this government has failed to appoint new members to it, and it has been retained only in form and not as an operational body. Yesterday we had the republic debate, when once again the government showed that it would not accept the views of anyone that did not agree with it. The Prime Minister was hell-bent on making sure that he presents a question to the Australian people that is in line with his ideas and that provides him with the best opportunity to get the result he wants. He totally ignored the recommendation of a bipartisan committee. Today we have the government introducing legislation to abolish an independent board and independent councils. It is very much the way this government operates. You have to agree with it, you have to follow its ideology, or else you are out. So yesterday it was the report and the recommendations of the Joint Select Committee on the Republic Referendum; today it is NBEET.
I support the amendment moved by the shadow minister, who is committed to a whole-of-life cross-sectional approach to education. He recognises the importance of a knowledge and skill based society. We must have a cross-sectional approach to education, training and employment. We live in a changing society where education, training, skills and employment needs are paramount. We are looking at very different types of issues in these areas from those we looked at in the past. We are looking at the need for accreditation, credit transfer and pathways. Even school education is very different from the way it used to be. You have students who are involved in vocational education where part of their schooling is done within the traditional classroom, another part of their education may be done at TAFE and another part of their education may be obtaining skills out in the work force.
Our education system, our approach to learning, training and developing skills must be able to encompass this. But I am afraid that this government does not feel that way. That is why it is abolishing the board. That is why it is going to abolish the councils—cost-effective bodies that provided advice to government on education and training for a number of years. The government does not want advice, because it is caught in its ideological warp. Australians are being disadvantaged and left behind because of this government's approach. Governments need independent bodies that can stand back, review policies and make recommendations for new policies and new initiatives. They need to get advice from bodies other than the departments, and they need to get ideas that go outside their own cabinet, their own party room, But this government refuses to do that. You need to look at what works and what does not work. You need to recommend new strategies to meet the needs of our high-tech society. If we do not do that, Australia is going to be left behind. And that is what this government is doing: putting Australia in a position where it will be left behind the rest of the world.
Unfortunately, this government is so tightly locked into its ideology and its 1950s view of 
 Australia that it continues to attack those programs that do not match its philosophy. We have seen the Jobskills program go. We have seen changes to apprenticeships that are disadvantaging young Australians. The Jobtrain program, a skill based program that provided training to people in areas that were identified as areas of need, has gone. LEAP, a program that was designed to help young Australians get skills and formal qualifications while getting experience working on the job, has gone. What has it been replaced with? Work for the Dole. It is a narrow approach that is designed to say, `If you are getting any sort of assistance from the government, we want you to go out and work and pay for it.' It is not about getting skills, it is not about getting education and it is not about getting training.
This government stands condemned for its failure to deliver the programs that will meet the educational and training needs of Australians, a failure that is leading to a society where Australians lack the skills they need to find employment in a highly technical, knowledge based society. The amendment moved by the shadow minister would assist Australians to meet the challenge of the new millennium—something that John Howard's 1950s style government cannot do and something that attacks on independent bodies like NBEET and its councils will not achieve.
Sitting suspended from 6.30 p.m. to 8.00 p.m.

name: Snowdon, Warren, MP
text:
—Thank you, Mr Speaker, for that advice. I am sure we will all be rugging up progressively into the evening.
—The member for the Northern Territory need not feel any obligation to add any heat to the argument.
—I will not, but I am pleased that we do not have lots of wooden chairs—we have some, actually—but we need to watch out that there are no bonfires around the place.
—I assure you that there is no risk or, of course, the place would have been evacuated.
—I certainly hope so, but you never know.
It is well to remind ourselves that the Employment, Education and Training Amendment Bill 1999, which is before us, abolishes the National Board of Employment, Education and Training—NBEET—and four of its five councils. The Australian Research Council will be retained and will report directly to the minister. The issue for us is what this means for education in Australia. The abolition points to a new method of advising the government. It is clear that the government's preoccupation with outcomes has led to the demise of a holistic approach to issues. The replacement is a fragmented model that denies the opportunity for various interests within a policy area to work together to develop a coordinated approach and to reach a consensus of opinion on policy issues.
I will refer specifically to the Schools Council. The purpose of the Schools Council was to provide advice and information as requested by the minister, by the national board or on its own initiative on primary and secondary education in Australia. The membership of the council was broadly based, with representation from the government and non-government school sectors, teaching unions, businesses, and community and parent organisations. Abolition of the Schools Council means that no mechanism is now in place to bring together representatives from all the key sectors and organisations with an interest in school education to formulate independent advice to the government reached through a consensus of opinion by all interests.
The advice mechanisms the government now has in place are therefore not holistic. They are one-dimensional, fragmented, ad hoc and formulated on an issue-by-issue basis without consideration for the totality of the school education environment. It is worth noting that, in its submission to this year's budget, the organisation so often maligned in this place by the minister—the Australian Education Union—called for the establishment of a schools advisory council as a principal forum to advise both the Commonwealth and state governments on national schooling policy.
The demise of the Australian Language and Literacy Council has had a similar impact in the area of advice to government on literacy. The role of the ALLC was to provide advice to the minister on priorities, strategies and targets for the development and implementation of the Australian language and literacy policy. Its membership included representatives from educational institutions, Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander organisations, linguists, educationalists and industry.
There is a certain irony, given this government's asserted focus on literacy matters across the spectrum, that it has no peak industry body to advise it in this area. As with the abolition of the Schools Council, there is no longer a body that can provide what I regard as a holistic approach to providing advice to government on literacy matters. The problems caused by this vacuum have 
 been further exacerbated by the government's cut in core funding to Language Australia, which now has to rely on project funding for its survival. The purpose of Language Australia is to coordinate and undertake research, conduct professional development and produce and disseminate information about language, literacy and multicultural issues.
That is particularly relevant in the context of the Northern Territory. You would be aware, Mr Speaker, that the Northern Territory has a very diverse population, is multicultural and multilingual. More than half of the schools and a quarter of its students are located in remote areas and suffer severe disadvantages. School-age children comprise 25 per cent of the population. That is more than in any other state or territory. Indigenous students comprise 34 per cent of the total student population of 40,000.
Mr Speaker, you will recall that, during a previous session of this parliament late last year, I asked a question of the Prime Minister on bilingual education which he refused to answer. I took umbrage at his lack of response and I was quietly, although not without some verbal resistance, evicted from the chamber. I took no pride in that, Mr Speaker, but it was a sign of my frustration and a demonstration of the frustration that many of my constituents feel about the response of this government on issues to do with literacy and language and in particular on the issue of bilingual education.
That frustration is ongoing and we have not had an adequate response from this government on the issue of bilingual education. Indeed, it is still an issue which is causing a great deal of concern in many Aboriginal schools around the Northern Territory and within the Aboriginal community and education fraternity generally. You may be aware, Mr Speaker, that the Northern Territory government's unilateral decision to axe bilingual education for Aboriginal students was believed by many to be inexcusable and to not have a valid basis. It has caused enormous anxiety. I am paraphrasing there the words of Chris Sidoti, the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commissioner. He was speaking after hearing submissions from the 
 Yolngu people at the Yirrkala school near Nhulunbuy. Mr Sidoti had said there that there was concern about the loss of bilingual education programs and that it was swamping his national education inquiry. I want to quote what he had to say:
The message that we are getting loud and unequivocally from Aboriginal people is that they want their kids to be fluent and literate in English and in their own language.
This he told the Canberra Times  on Friday, 14 May this year. He went on:
It is not a rejection of the importance of English. On the contrary, they are saying that they want English skills of a higher level than present because they see the English language as being the only passport into the world of most Australians.
I am acutely aware of this concern and of the frustration and hurt that is being felt not only by Aboriginal students but also by their parents and their communities at the failure of not only this government but also the Northern Territory government to respond to the legitimate requests to have this program reinstated.	 There is currently an inquiry under way in the Northern Territory being undertaken on behalf of the Northern Territory government by a former Senate colleague of ours, Bob Collins, who was, as you would be aware, Mr Speaker, a former minister in the Labor government.
It is very hard to describe, in a way which this parliament will understand, the enormous concern that Aboriginal Territorians have for this issue, but this concern is shared by those who are involved in providing education to them—not only in the government school system but also in the non-government school sector. It is worth pointing out that some of the loudest concerns have been expressed by the Catholic system. In the context of the government system, I visited communities such us Yuendumu and Willowra where people demanded the right to be able to give their views to the minister of the day in the Northern Territory and to have me express on their behalf their views to this parliament.
I was left in the position last year, Mr Speaker, where, when I asked a question of the Prime Minister, which was then deflected to the Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs, not only was he unable to 
 answer the question but his arrogant response left me with little option but to raise my concerns forcibly in this place. The sanctions which were applied were no doubt legitimate, but I make no apologies for raising that issue and I make no apologies for continuing to raise it. I say to the government and to the minister responsible for education that, when he is blithely talking about his achievements and what his government's policies are, he ought to pay some credence to what the communities around Australia, and particularly in the Northern Territory, are demanding of him and his government as well as the government of the Northern Territory. They ought to be aware that this issue of bilingual education is regarded by Aboriginal communities right throughout the Territory as non-negotiable. It is not an issue about which they have a choice.
It is not just a question about improving literacy in English, it is a fundamental issue about cultural maintenance, and that seems to have bypassed this parliament, or at least this minister and this government, because if they had an interest or an understanding they would be demanding that the Northern Territory government immediately reinstate the program. If the minister is not able to do that, then he should be making funds available so that these programs are directly funded in the Northern Territory, and the Northern Territory government is bypassed. That is possible. Indeed, when the Labor Party is re-elected to office I will be advocating that course. It seems to me that we have to be able to respond to the wishes of the community. I note that the minister is prepared to respond readily and quickly to the demands of the non-government school sector, yet in the context of the demands of the government school sector it is as if their pleas fall on deaf ears. They have certainly fallen on deaf ears in the context of Aboriginal bilingual education in the Northern Territory.
It is also worth pointing out that this week in the Northern Territory the Australian Education Union is boycotting the transmission of MAP, multilevel assessment program tests, until the Northern Territory government restores the bilingual education program. The 
 MAP program is to be administered to year 3 and 5 students throughout the next two years. The tests have been in the Northern Territory for the last 15 years.
This week teachers throughout the Northern Territory are considering whether or not they will be administering the MAP test and have threatened that they will not administer it. They will be reporting back to their organisation this week after meetings in Tennant Creek, Nhulunbuy and Katherine on Thursday and Friday. But the union is expecting to hear back from the Northern Territory government, who are jumping fast. The union has had meetings yesterday and today with Northern Territory Minister Adamson, who in the context of a hierarchy of dills around Australia is probably the biggest. The Northern Territory government has said it will come back, possibly tomorrow.
Action is being taken because of misuse of MAP data to discredit the bilingual education program. The teachers also want an undertaking that the information be confidential to each school community, which was certainly not the case with the bilingual education decision and the decision to close Traeger Park School in Alice Springs. It had been used publicly as an excuse to knock off the bilingual program and to close the Traeger Park School. They also want an undertaking that the information will be confidential to each school community, which has certainly not been the case. The benchmark data is used in reporting to the Commonwealth, which is used by the Commonwealth to determine the funding which goes to the Northern Territory.
The union, rightly, wants a guarantee for the number of positions involved and the resources available to the bilingual education program. It is very clear that this MAP data has been misused in the past, and it rightfully wants guarantees that it will not happen in the future. The Northern Territory government illegitimately compared bilingual and non-bilingual education schools when they have enormously different factors involved in their assessment, not the least of which are their geography and the nature of their school populations. It is a completely illegitimate use 
 of the MAP data to use it as a reason to close the bilingual education program. They used the same data to close the progressive Traeger Park School.
These things are happening today. It seems that the Northern Territory government is only worried about the outcomes in Aboriginal schools when the data received from them is concerned with raising money from the Commonwealth. The system-wide programs in the Northern Territory have not been used properly, and it is clear that the data which is being collected on behalf of the minister here in this place is being used to discriminate against certain schools with regard to their achievements. Students who are not achieving up to standard will suffer, and there is no benchmark test or program in place for the allocation of extra resources to address these needs. The minister here has said that it is the schools' responsibility, that they will get as much each year as they require to get all students up to scratch. The fact is that this has not happened.
We hear a lot in this place, and I have heard outside this place, about issues to do with community development and the role of training and employment. Fundamental to all of these things, to improving the community benefit, to improving the social capital of this country, is a foundation in education. I will not have time tonight to talk about education in remote and rural Australia and for isolated children but I would like to, because they too have been disadvantaged by decisions of this government and the Northern Territory government, and I am sure by other state and territory governments. What is clear in terms of the resources that are required to provide people with the basic skills, whether it is literacy and numeracy, social skills or whatever, is that a large proportion of the school population outside of the major metropolitan areas is missing out. So obviously when they go and compete for jobs in a tight labour market they do not have the skills required not only to get the job but also to get into the most basic foundational education program in a post-school environment, in a pre-vocation program. 
Is it their fault? Is it the community's fault? Invariably it is not their fault. Invariably it is the fault of governments, who have the responsibility to allocate resources and to respond to community wishes and community demands. But also invariably, and I might say almost as a matter of course, governments nationally and at a state and territory level do not adopt this strategy. If we are to improve the educational outcomes and therefore the employment outcomes and promote industry development on a regional basis, there is a fundamental requirement for us to accept and understand that regions across Australia differ, that states and territories have different demands and that within their boundaries those demands differ. We have to accept that we need to address those demands in a way which achieves the outcomes which are best suited to those particular communities and regions.
